para.para.text: This topic contains forms and related material for use in administrative and judicial proceedings pertaining to customs duties and import regulations. Coverage includes administrative and United States Court of International Trade proceedings pertaining to ascertainment of customs duties on imports.

para.para.text: The Constitution of the United States confers on Congress the power to lay and collect taxes, duties, imposts, and excises. This constitutional authority to levy duties on imports and the prohibition against duties on exports applies exclusively to foreign trade. Although the taxing power of Congress is distinct from the power to regulate commerce with foreign nations, duties may be imposed as a commerce regulation. That duties are so imposed is well established. The imposition of customs duties is a legislative act whether done directly by Congress or under its authorization within limits prescribed by it. The tests of the validity of an enactment imposing customs duties are, therefore, primarily those applied to legislation generally; and a change of the tariff laws is not subject to impeachment on the score of invalidity because made without notice to, or hearing of, those affected. All duties and imposts are required by the Constitution to be uniform throughout the United States. Except for the existence of treaties unabrogated or unrepealed in an act of Congress itself, Congress has full authority, in levying duties on importations of merchandise, to discriminate as between nations. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;6 et seq.

Statutes imposing customs duties are remedial in character rather than penal, since they are intended to prevent fraud, suppress public wrong, and promote the public good. They are to be construed so as to carry out the intention of Congress in passing them and most effectually to accomplish these objects. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §89.

The collection of customs duties is conducted under the superintendence of the Secretary of the Treasury. Statutory provision is made for the United States Custom Service and the Department of the Treasury, with the Commissioner of Customs as the Head of the Service, and the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to appoint, and to prescribe the duties of, the personnel of the service. When foreign merchandise is entered at a domestic port and the owner has filed his or her statutory declaration, together with a bill of lading and, in such instances as the Secretary of the Treasury determines by regulation, a certified invoice for the goods sought to be imported, such goods are examined and appraised. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;133, 134, 168, 169.

The Secretary of the Treasury is required to establish and promulgate such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the law and may disseminate such information as may be necessary to secure a just, impartial, and uniform appraisement of imported merchandise in the classification and assessment of duties on same. The Customs Service must, under rules and regulations prescribed by the Secretary:

appraise merchandise in the unit of quantity in which the merchandise is usually bought and sold by ascertaining or estimating its value by all reasonable ways and means in the Customs Service's power, any statement of cost or costs of production in any invoice, affidavit, declaration, or other document to the contrary notwithstanding;
ascertain the classification and rate of duty applicable to the merchandise;
fix the amount of duty to be paid on the merchandise and determine any increased or additional duties due or any excess of duties deposited;
liquidate the entry of the merchandise; and

give notice of liquidation to the importer, the importer's consignee, or agent in such form and manner as the Secretary shall prescribe in the regulations.4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §181, 182.

para.para.text: This division consists of forms and material relating to administrative requests to the Commissioner of Customs, protests of decisions of District Directors of Customs, and administrative review of those decisions, including a pertinent checklist and text for use in drafting such forms.

A prerequisite [*TEST CREATE DATE*] to any action alleging illegal exactions of duties is that payment must be paid under protest. Under the customs statutes, with some exceptions, decisions of the Customs Service are final and conclusive on all parties unless a protest is filed or unless a civil action contesting the denial of a protest is commenced in the United States Court of International Trade within the time prescribed by statute. Such a protest must be filed in writing with the Customs Service, and may be filed by the importer, consignee, or any authorized agent of the person paying any charge or exaction, or filing any claim for drawback, or seeking any entry or delivery, with respect to merchandise which is the subject of the Custom Service's decision. The actual owner and ultimate consignee of imported goods has the right to file a protest, either on its own behalf or as an agent of the importer of record. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §192.

The protest must be filed with the Customs Service within 90 days after the date of notice of liquidation or reliquidation, or within 90 days of the date of a decision involving neither a liquidation or reliquidation or the date of mailing of notice of demand for payment against a bond in the case of a surety who has an unsatisfied legal claim under a bond written by the surety. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;194, 200 to 204.

The number of protests that may be filed against decisions made as to imported merchandise is limited by statute. Only one protest may be filed for each entry of merchandise, except that where the entry covers merchandise of different categories, a separate protest may be filed for each category. Separate protests filed by different authorized persons with respect to any one category of merchandise that is the subject of a protest will be deemed to be part of a single protest. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §195.

A protest must be in writing and must set forth distinctly and specifically each decision by the Customs Service as to which protest is made; each category of merchandise affected by the decision as to which protest is made; and the nature of each objection and reasons therefor. Objections based on irregularities in the Customs Service appraisal should be specific; if they are too general, they will not be considered. Generally, the protestant is required not only to point out that his or her merchandise is not dutiable under the provisions on which the Customs Service relies, but the protestant must also point out where in the tariff act it is dutiable, if anywhere. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §196.

The rules of the Customs Service set forth in Title 19 of the Code of Federal Regulations prescribe the contents of a protest in detail, most of which requirements are reflected in Customs Form 19, which is reproduced below. The protestant is not required to use any particular form of protest, however, it being sufficient if the importer indicates distinctly and definitely the source of his or her complaint and the importer's design to make it the foundation for a claim against the government. Additionally, a protest should be liberally construed, and alternative claims are permitted. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §196.

A protest may be amended any time prior to the expiration of the time in which the original protest could have been filed to assert additional claims pertaining to the administrative decision that is the subject of the protest, or may challenge an additional administrative decision relating to the same category of merchandise that is the ground of the protest. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §197.

Unless a request for an accelerated disposition of a protest is filed, the Customs Service, within the statutory time, must review the protest and allow or deny the same in whole or in part. Unless a protest is filed in accordance with the statute, or unless a civil action contesting the denial of a protest is commenced in the Court of International Trade, or except as otherwise provided, decisions of the Customs Service are final. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;23 to 60.5, 82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;198, 199, 207 to 210, 248.
The abbreviation "TSUS" appearing in materials throughout this article refers to Tariff Schedules of the United States.

outline.name.block.name: ChecklistDrafting protest to Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection against classification of merchandise by port director for purpose of fixing customs duties

para.para.text: Checklist of matters, inter alia, that should be alleged in a protest to a District Director of Customs against the classification of merchandise by the Collector of Customs for the purpose of fixing customs duties:
Protestant.
Name.
Address.
Importer number.
District in which port where entry was made is situated.
Number and date of entry of merchandise.
Date of liquidation of entry (or date of decision).
Name of importing carrier.
Specific description of subject merchandise.
As to each category of merchandise.
Nature and justification for objection to the classification made.
Allegation of correct classification of the merchandise in question.
If protesting party requests disposition of protest in accordance with action taken on protest previously filed that is the subject of pending application for further review, protest must also show:
Date of receipt of previously filed protest; and
Protest number of previously filed protest.

If surety is filing protest where another party has not filed a timely protest, certification that surety's protest is not being filed collusively to extend another authorized person's time to protest.

outline.name.block.name: CertificateBy carrierRight to make customs entry

form.para.form.text: The undersigned carrier, to whom or on whose order the articles described in this certificate or in the attached document must be released, certifies that the consignee named in this document is the owner or consignee of the articles within the purview of Section 484(h) of the Tariff Act of 1930. In accordance with the provisions of Section 484(j) of the Tariff Act of 1930, authority is given to release the articles covered by the mentioned statement to the consignee for transfer to the bonded warehouse designated in the warehouse entry or for transfer to the bonded carrier designated in the transportation entry or for transfer to the carrier designated in the export entry or for transfer to the foreign trade zone designated in Customs Form 214.

name.block.name: PRO FORMA INVOICE IMPORTER'S STATEMENT OF VALUE OR THE PRICE PAID IN THE FORM OF AN INVOICE

form.para.form.text: Not being in possession of a commercial seller's or shipper's invoice, I request that you accept the statement of value or the price paid in the form of an invoice submitted below:
Name of shipper:
Shipper's address:
Name of seller:
Seller's address:
Name of consignee:
Consignee's address:
Name of purchaser:
Purchaser's address:
The merchandise [has/has not] been purchased or agreed to be purchased by me.
The prices, or in the case of consigned goods, the values, given below are true and correct to the best of my knowledge, and are based on [selection of appropriate option]:
The price paid or agreed to be paid as per order dated: [date of order]
Advices from exporter by letter or by cable, dated: [date of letter or cable]

outline.name.block.name: RequestTo Commissioner of Customs and Border ProtectionFor information as to classification and rate of duty imposed on designated imported merchandise

form.para.form.text: This company is a corporation duly organized under the laws of [name of state], engaged in the business of [description of business], with its principal place of business located at [address of business], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state]. [Name of corporation] is a domestic interested party and requests the information specified below pursuant to Title 19 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Section 175.1.

[Name of corporation] intends to import certain drill pipe-tool joint combinations for use in boring operations for oil and gas. The probable port of entry is [description of port], and the manufacturer is [name of company] of [name of country of manufacturer]. Before entering into any contractual agreements, it is essential that we obtain a ruling as to the proper tariff classification of the contemplated import. Therefore, we request such a ruling and further ask that this request be processed on an expedited basis and that the ruling be issued as soon as possible.

The article in its imported condition consists of [description of material or materials of which article is composed and description of component material which is of chief value.] The dimensions of the article are [description of dimensions]. The [description of article] is used in the following manner: [description of how apparatus functions or operates], and will be used for the following purposes: [description of purposes].
We contend that the proper classification for this article is in Item [number of item] of the Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS) for the following reasons:

The only use to which the article in question, drill pipe-tool joint combinations, can be put is in boring operations for oil and gas. Therefore, classification as part of boring machinery is proper absent a specific provision for this article.
The drill pipe-tool joint combinations are very similar to the drill collars that were found to be classifiable as boring machinery in the case of U. S. v. Servo Co., 477 F.2d 579 (C.C.P.A. 1973).

We submit that the above facts sufficiently establish a basis for classification under Item [number of item] of the Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), and we request that Headquarters so rule.

Part 181, Subpart 1, as to whether the goods described below qualify for duty-free treatment in accordance with 19 C.F.R. §181.64 on re-entry to the United States after having been exported from the United States to Mexico for repair or alteration.

At the time the goods are returned to the United States, the declarations required by 19 C.F.R. §181.64 would be filed in connection with the re-entry, along with any other documentation required by the district director to substantiate actual exportation of the goods from the United States for repair or alteration.

To the knowledge of the undersigned, a transaction similar or identical to the above-described transaction has never been considered by any Customs Service office, or by the United States Court of International Trade, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, or any court of appeal.
The prospective transaction described in this request for ruling is but one of a series of similar and related transactions.
The following samples relating to this request are included with it: [identification of [representations/samples] of described goods].

The undersigned believes that the ruling issued pursuant to this request should be that the above-described alteration process would neither destroy the essential characteristics of the goods exported from the United States, nor create new or commercially different goods from the goods exported from the United States. In support of this determination or conclusion, the undersigned provides the following information: [statement of basis for determination, together with supporting authority].

form.para.form.text: Commissioner of Customs
United States Customs Service
Attention: Classification and Value decision
[Salutation]:

My name is [name of petitioner]. I am the [description of corporate title of/attorney for] [name of corporation], a corporation duly organized under the laws of [name of state], with its principal place of business located at [address of business], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state]. [Name of corporation] is a domestic interested party as defined in [citation of code of federal regulations; if a manufacturer: 19 C.F.R. §175.3(a)], in that it is a manufacturer of [description of product], a product like that described below.

By letter Dated: [date of letter], I requested information as to the proper tariff classification of certain designated imported merchandise. A copy of that letter is attached for reference. By letter Dated: [date of letter], Customs responded to my request by stating that the proper tariff classification of such merchandise is [description of tariff]. I believe that this classification is not correct, and I therefore petition for review of the determination pursuant to 19 U.S.C.A. §1516(a), and 19 C.F.R. Part.175, Subpart B. The grounds for the petition are as follows:

The article in its imported condition consists of [description of material or materials of which article is composed, with specification of component material which is of chief value]. The dimensions of the article are [description of dimensions]. The [description of article] is used in the following manner: [description of how apparatus functions or operates], and will be used for the following purposes: [statement of purposes].
I contend that the proper classification for this article is subheading [description of subheading] of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States (HTSUS), for the following reasons:

The only use to which the article in question, (drill pipe-tool joint combinations), can be put is in boring operations for oil and gas. Therefore, classification as part of boring machinery is proper absent a specific provision for this article.
The drill pipe-tool joint combinations are very similar to the drill collars which were found to be classifiable as boring machinery in the case of U. S. v. Servo Co., 477 F.2d 579 (C.C.P.A. 1973).

form.text.inline.instr: [Description of class or kind of merchandise manufactured (or produced or sold) by petitioner which is claimed to be similar to imported merchandise in question.]

form.para.form.text: I submit that the above facts sufficiently establish a basis for classification under subheading [description of subheading], HTSUS, and not subheading [description of subheading], HTSUS, as stated by Customs by letter Dated: [date of letter], and I request that Customs change its determination accordingly.

outline.name.block.name: ProtestTo Commissioner of Customs and Border ProtectionBy importerErroneous classification of merchandise by Bureau of Customs and Border Protection

form.name.block.name: PROTEST

caption.block.form.line: To: the District Director of Customs, District of [description of district]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of importer], the undersigned, importer number [importer number], protest against the assessment and collection of $[dollar amount] customs duties on 200 tons of [description of goods], which entered the United States on [date of entry], by [description of means of entry] on at [place of importation].
The above-described goods were duly entered at the above-named [place of importation] on [date of entry], entry number [number of entry], and the entry was liquidated: on [date of liquidation].

The above-described [description of goods] were classified as [description of classification] under the Tariff Act of 1930 (United States Code, Title 19), and on the strength of the classification were assessed for duties at the rate of [description of assessment]. This classification is erroneous, in that [statement of reasons why protestant believes classification erroneous].

The correct classification of the above-described merchandise is [statement of desired classification] under the provisions of [citation of section of Tariff Act], for the following reasons: [statement, in separately designated paragraphs, of specific factual material and legal arguments that protestant believes support protest].
For the reasons set forth above, the correct rate of duties to be paid on the above-described [description of goods] is thus $[dollar amount] instead of $[dollar amount].

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

para.para.text: In practice, a protest must be filed in quadruplicate on Customs Form 19, set forth in §9, obtainable from a district director of the Customs Service, or a form of the same size clearly labeled "Protest" and setting forth the same content in its entirety, in essentially the same order. All schedules or other attachments to a protest (other than samples or similar exhibits) must also be filed in quadruplicate (19 C.F.R. §174.12(b)). The protest must be signed by the person filing it, or his or her agent or attorney. If the individual filing the protest is not the importer of record or the consignee, that individual must include his or her address and importer number, if any (19 C.F.R. §174.12(c)).

statnote.note.text: Protests must be filed with the district director of the Customs Service whose decision is protested except that, when the entry underlying the decision protested is filed at a port other than the district headquarters, the protest may be filed with the port director at that port (19 C.F.R. §174.12(d)).

para.para.text: Protests must be filed within 90 days after the date of notice of liquidation or reliquidation, or the date of a decision involving neither a liquidation or reliquidation or the date of mailing of notice of demand for payment against a bond in the case of a surety which has an unsatisfied legal claim under a bond written by the surety (19 U.S.C.A. §1514(c)(2); 19 C.F.R. §174.12(e)).

statnote.note.text: Only one protest may be filed for each entry of merchandise, except that when the entry covers merchandise of different categories, a separate protest may be filed for each category. Separate protests filed by different authorized persons with respect to any one category of merchandise that is the subject of a protest will be deemed to be part of a single protest (19 U.S.C.A. §1514(c)(1)).
The date on which a protest is received by the Customs officer with whom it is required to be filed is the date on which it is deemed filed (19 C.F.R. §174.12(f)).

para.para.text: For requirements of protest, see &dblsect;12 and 13.

form.name.block.name: PROTEST

caption.block.form.line: To: the District Director of Customs, District of [description of district]

form.para.form.text: Notice of dissatisfaction is given with, and protest is made by [name of protestant] against, the Customs Service's decision, liquidation, and assessment of duties at [percentage rate]% under Item [number of item] or other rate or rates on [description of articles] and other similar merchandise described on or covered by the entries named below. The reasons for objection under the Tariff Act of 1930, as amended, and the Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), as amended, are as follows:
We claim that the merchandise is properly dutiable at [percentage rate]% under Item [number of item], TSUS.
We further claim that the assessment of the duties made by the Customs Service is illegal and void.

The above claims severally and collectively are alternatively made directly under the item or sections cited, and under all applicable headnotes and rules of interpretation, and by virtue of the "similitude" clauses of Items 798.00 and 798.50, TSUS, and under the rules relating to the ordinary meaning of words or the commercial designation of the merchandise.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

para.para.text: Requirement that protest must distinctly and specifically with respect to each category, payment, claim, decision, or refusal, set forth the nature of, and justification for, the objection. 19 C.F.R. §174.13(a)(6).
For requirements of protest, see &dblsect;12 and 13.

The above protest is adapted from a protest filed in Knowles Electronics v. U. S., 71 Cust. Ct. 112, 371 F. Supp. 1393 (Cust. Ct. 1973), judgment aff'd, 504 F.2d 1403 (C.C.P.A. 1974), in which the government admitted in its answer that some of the protested articles were improperly classified and judgment was entered sustaining the protest to that extent.

The objections stated in a protest must be so distinct and specific as to show, when fairly construed, that the objection later taken at the trial was in the mind of the importer at the time of protest and that the Customs Service was notified of the true nature and character of the protest, to the end that the Customs Service might ascertain the precise facts and have an opportunity to correct the mistake or cure the defect, if it was one that could be obviated. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §196.

Generally, the protestant is also required to point out where in the Tariff Act the merchandise is dutiable, if anywhere, as well as to point out that the protestant's merchandise is not dutiable under the provisions on which the Customs Service relies. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §196.

Generally, also, a protest that claims dissatisfaction under a specified provision of the tariff statute is sufficient although the article imported could be so classified only by virtue of the "similitude" clause. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §196.

The above protest was filed in Midwood Industries, Inc. v. U. S., 64 Cust. Ct. 499, 313 F. Supp. 951 (Cust. Ct. 3 Div. 1970), in which three of the protests of exclusion of merchandise for improper marking as to country of origin were sustained and two were overruled. The court held that where imported goods had to undergo further manufacturing processes before they could be made available to the buying public, the manufacturer was the "ultimate purchaser" of the material within the meaning of 19 U.S.C.A. §1304(a)(3)(H).

para.para.text: Review and disposition of protests. 19 C.F.R. &dblsect;174.21 et seq.

The above report was filed after administrative review of one of the protests which were the basis for Knowles Electronics v. U. S., 504 F.2d 1403 (C.C.P.A. 1974). The decision as to the above report was then upheld by both the Customs Court and the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals (Cust).

"District director" means the district director of Customs at a headquarters port other than the port of New York, New York; at the latter port, the term means the regional commissioner of Customs for Customs Region II. 19 C.F.R. §174.1(a).

A protest per se is not a cause of action at all. Instead, by virtue of 28 U.S.C.A. §2632(a), the denial of a protest, in whole or in part, creates a right of action. Thus, for an importer to contest judicially the liquidation of an entry of imported merchandise, not only must the importer initially file a protest with regard to that entry, but also, following denial of the protest on the administrative level, the importer must commence a civil action with respect to the entry by the timely filing of a summons. Where a protest is allowed as to one entry, but denied as to another, no right of action exists as to the former. Further, a summons may be limited in content to fewer entries than were covered by the administrative protest, denial of which is being challenged. Border Brokerage Co., Inc. v. U. S., 72 Cust. Ct. 93, 372 F. Supp. 1389 (Cust. Ct. 1974).

para.para.text: This division consists of forms and material relating to proceedings in the United States Court of International Trade, including the summons and other preliminary forms; complaints and motions directed to the pleadings; forms pertaining to dismissal; forms pertaining to discovery and depositions; forms pertaining to pretrial proceedings; summary judgment and (mgc) judgments; and notice of appeal. Jill.

The Customs Courts Act of 1980 established the United States Court of International Trade as the successor to the United States Customs Court. The Court of International Trade has adopted rules of practice and procedure to replace the old Customs Courts rules. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.28 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;1581 et seq.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;250 et seq.

The Customs Courts Act of 1980, 28 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;1581 et seq., provides that the Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction of any civil action brought to contest the denial of a protest, in whole or in part, under specified provisions of the Tariff Act of 1930, any civil action brought under provisions of the Tariff Act, as well as other specified jurisdiction. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.28 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;1581 et seq.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;250 et seq.

The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction to render judgment on any counterclaim, cross-claim, or third-party action of any party, if the action or claim involved the imported merchandise that is the subject matter of a civil action or the claim or action is to recover on a bond or customs duties relating to such merchandise. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.28 U.S.C.A. §1583.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;250 et seq.

The Court of International Trade also has exclusive jurisdiction of civil actions brought pursuant to statute by American manufacturers, producers, or wholesalers. However, it is provided that the Court of International Trade will not have jurisdiction of an action unless either a protest has been filed and denied or, if the action relates to a decision made under a specified statutory provision, if all remedies prescribed have been exhausted. Except in the case of an action relating to a decision under a specified statute, all liquidated: duties, charges, or exactions must have been paid at the time the action is filed. In addition, the party bringing the suit must have standing to sue with regard to the customs determination being contested. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;250 et seq.

The Court of International Trade has all the powers at law and equity of, or as conferred by statute on, a District Court of the United States. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.28 U.S.C.A. §1585.

The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has jurisdiction of appeals from all judgments or orders of the United States Court of International Trade, and certain interlocutory orders. The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit also has jurisdiction to review, by appeal on questions of law only, the findings of the United States International Trade Commission as to unfair practices in import trade. The Supreme Court has appellate jurisdiction over the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §251 to 253, 256 to 277, 281 to 285.

After the filing and service of the summons, a plaintiff who desires to try or otherwise prosecute an action must serve on the opposite party and file with the Court of International Trade a complaint. The Rules of the Court of International Trade (cited as CIT Rules) prescribe the form of pleadings and the contents of the various types of complaints that may be filed. A defendant who desires to have an action tried or otherwise prosecuted may serve on the opposite party and file with the court a demand for a complaint. On the service and filing of such a demand, the plaintiff, in the absence of other disposition, is required to timely serve on the opposite party and file with the court a complaint. The filing of a complaint removes an action from the reserve file, suspension, or the suspension disposition file. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. &dblsect;37:279 et seq.

The complaint in the Court of International Trade differs from the complaint in other federal courts, being more in the nature of a notice of intention to proceed to litigation, combined with a modified bill of particulars. An answer to the complaint must be filed. If the answer contains an alternative claim or counterclaim a reply must be made. A reply to the answer may be ordered even if the answer does not contain an alternative claim or counterclaim. The Rules of the Court of International Trade prescribe the content and form of an answer. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. &dblsect;37:302 et seq.

Except for jurisdictional defenses, the party waives all defenses not set forth in its answer or reply or presented by motion. An alternative claim or affirmative defense may be made in an answer. The purpose of the answer is to apprise the plaintiff of the allegations in the complaint that are admitted, and therefore not at issue at trial, and those that are contested. 9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:307.

This subdivision consists (mgc)of forms and material relating to the filing of a summons to commence a civil action in the United States Court of International Trade, along with forms of proof of service and notice and acknowledgment of receipt of a summons and complaint. Also included are certain preliminary forms that must or may also be filed, including a notice of lawsuit and request for waiver of service of process, the waiver of service, an information statement, and a disclosure of corporate affiliations and financial interests.

Most actions are commenced in the Court of International Trade by the filing of a summons and complaint. However, only the filing of a summons is required to commence an action under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(a) to challenge the denial of a protest, or an action under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b) to challenge an adverse determination on a petition regarding the appraisal, classification, or rate of duty on imported merchandise. These actions are placed on the Reserve or Suspension Calendars if no complaint is filed with the summons. An action challenging an antidumping or countervailing duty determination under 19 U.S.C.A. §1516a(a)(2) is commenced by the filing of a summons, and the complaint must be filed within 30 days after the filing of the summons. All other antidumping and countervailing duty actions authorized by 19 U.S.C.A. §1516a are commenced by the filing of a summons and complaint. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:279.

A plaintiff should use the form of summons prescribed for the particular action. The instructions to each form state how many copies must be filed. It is essential that the summons state the proper name of the plaintiff, although the court's jurisdiction is not affected by the fact that the protests were made in the name of a corporate division instead of the corporate plaintiff, so long as the plaintiff and the protests are properly identified in the summons. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:279.

A completed information statement must be filed when an action is commenced. This statement is available from the clerk, is similar to a civil cover sheet in appearance, and performs similar administrative functions. An original and one copy of the information statement must be filed. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:280.

In addition, a disclosure statement must be filed by attorneys for: (1) subsidiaries of publicly-owned corporations that are not parties to the action; (2) parties to actions challenging the denial of protests or action on appraisal, classification, and rate of duty petitions who are not the ultimate consignee or real party in interest; and (3) trade associations. The disclosure statement is also required as to a corporation or trade association seeking to intervene or to appear as amicus curiae in any action. The disclosure statement helps the judges determine whether disqualification is required under 28 U.S.C.A. §455 on the ground of financial interest. This form is also available on request from the office of the clerk. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:280.

Under CIT Rule 3(b), in most cases, a $120 filing fee must be paid to the clerk of the court when an action is commenced. However, a $25 filing fee must be paid when an action to contest the denial of a protest or an action to review a determination on a petition regarding the classification, appraisal, or rate of duty on imported merchandise is filed. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:281.

A summons or a summons and complaint may be filed by either delivering or mailing the documents to the office of the clerk. The filing is generally completed when the papers are received by the clerk. However, the summons or summons and complaint will be deemed filed as of the date of mailing if they are mailed by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the clerk in a properly addressed and stamped envelope. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:282.

Service of process is governed by the CIT Rules. The clerk is responsible for serving a summons if the action may be commenced by filing a summons without a complaint. After serving the requisite government officials, the clerk must return a copy of the summons to the person who filed the summons, together with proof of service and a receipt for payment of the filing fee. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:284.

The plaintiff is responsible for the service of a summons and complaint, if the action is commenced by the filing of these documents. Under CIT Rule 4(c)(1), a summons and complaint may be served by any person who is not a party and who is not less than 18 years of age. At the request of the plaintiff, however, the court may direct that service be effected by a United States marshal or deputy United States marshal, or other court-appointed person or officer when the plaintiff is authorized to proceed in forma pauperis pursuant to statute. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:284.

Since all actions commenced by private parties must be brought against the government, a government official, or agency, service must comply with CIT Rule 4(i). This rule requires that service on the United States be made by serving the Attorney General, by delivering or mailing by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, a copy of the summons and complaint to the Attorney-in-Charge, International Trade Field Office, Commercial Litigation Branch, Department of Justice, and that service be made on an officer or agency of the United States by serving the United States, and by delivering or mailing by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, a copy of the summons and complaint to the officer or agency. Under CIT Rule 4(i)(2), federal agencies that are corporations may be served as any other corporation. 9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:285.

Under CIT Rule 4(l), (m), the person serving the process must make proof of service of such process to the clerk of the court within 120 days after the filing of the complaint. If service is made by a person other than a United States marshal or deputy United States marshal, such person must make an affidavit of the service. Failure to make proof of service does not affect the validity of the service. 10West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:286.

outline.name.block.name: Notice of lawsuit and request for waiver of service of summonsCIT Rules Appendix A, Form 1A

form.name.block.name: NOTICE OF LAWSUIT AND REQUEST FOR WAIVER OF SERVICE OF SUMMONS

form.para.form.text: To: [Name of individual defendant or name of officer or agent of corporate defendant] as [title or other relationship of individual to corporate defendant] of [name of corporate defendant, if any]

A lawsuit has been commenced against you or the entity on whose behalf you are addressed. A copy of the complaint is attached to this notice. It has been filed in the United States Court of International Trade and has been assigned Court Number [statement of docket number].

This is not a formal summons or notification from the court, but rather my request that you sign and return the enclosed waiver of service in order to save the cost of service of a summons and an additional copy of the complaint in this lawsuit. The cost of service will be avoided if I receive the signed copy of the waiver within [30 days/60 days (if the addressee is located in a foreign country)] after the date designated below as the date on which the Notice and Request is sent. I enclose a stamped and addressed envelope for your use. An extra copy of the waiver is also attached for your records.

If you comply with this request and return the signed waiver, it will be filed with the court and no summons will be served on you. The action will then proceed as if you had been served on the date the waiver is filed, except that you will not be obligated to answer the complaint before 60 days from the date designated below as the date on which this notice is sent (or before 90 days from that date if your address is not in any judicial district of the United States).

If you do not return the signed waiver within the time indicated, I will take appropriate steps to effect formal service in a manner authorized by the Rules of the Court of International Trade and will then, to the extent authorized by those Rules, ask the court to require you or the party on whose behalf you are addressed to pay the full costs of such service. In that connection, please read the statement concerning the duties of parties to waive the service of summons, which is set forth [on the reverse side/at the foot] of the waiver form.
I affirm that this request is being sent to you on behalf of the plaintiff on [date of request].

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

para.para.text: This form of Notice of Lawsuit and Request for Waiver of Service of Summons may be sent to the defendant prior to service of summons. CIT Rule 4(d)(2).

statnote.note.text: A Notice of Lawsuit and Request for Waiver of Service of Summons as prescribed by CIT Rule 4(d) must be addressed directly to a defendant and sent by first-class mail or other reliable means. The defendant must be allowed a reasonable period of time to return the waiver. Plaintiff must provide a defendant to whom the notice is addressed with a stamped and addressed return envelope, and also an extra copy of the waiver for defendant's records. On receipt of the signed waiver, plaintiff must file it with the court. CIT Rules, Appendix A, Forms, Instructions to Form 1A.
A defendant who waives service of a summons does not thereby waive any objection to the jurisdiction of the court over the person of the defendant. CIT Rule 4(d)(1).

para.para.text: For form of waiver mentioned in the above form, see §23.

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85

reference.entry.ref.text: Summons in proceeding in Court of International Trade. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:279

outline.name.block.name: Waiver of service of summonsCIT Rules Appendix A, Form 1B

form.name.block.name: WAIVER OF SERVICE OF SUMMONS

form.para.form.text: I acknowledge receipt of your request that I waive service of a summons in an action filed by you against my client, [name of defendant], Court Number [docket number] in the United States Court of International Trade. I have also received a copy of the complaint in this action, two copies of this instrument, and a means by which I can return the signed waiver to you without cost to me.

I agree to save the cost of service of a summons and an additional copy of the complaint in this lawsuit by not requiring that my client be served with judicial process in the manner provided by Rule 4 of the Rules of the Court of International Trade.
My client will retain all defenses or objections to the lawsuit or to the jurisdiction of the court except for objections based on a defect in the summons or in the service of the summons.

I understand that a judgment may be entered against my client if an answer or motion under Rule 12 of the Rules of the Court of International Trade is not served on you within 60 days after [date request was sent], or within 90 days after that date if the request was sent outside the United States.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

para.para.text: The following statement must be printed at the foot of the waiver form or on the reverse side of the above form with, in the latter case, a printed statement on the face of the form (such as "See Reverse Side for Important Notice") directing the reader's attention to the reverse side of the form: "Duty to Avoid Unnecessary Costs of Service of Summons.

statnote.note.text: This form of Waiver of Service of Summons is to be returned to a plaintiff who has requested a defendant to waive service. CIT Rules, Appendix A, Forms, Instructions to Form 1B.

A defendant that, before being served with process, timely returns a waiver requested by the plaintiff is not required to serve an answer to the complaint until 60 days after the date on which the request for waiver of service was sent, or 90 days after that date if the defendant was addressed outside any judicial district of the United States. CIT Rule 4(d)(3).
A defendant who waives service of a summons does not thereby waive any objection to the jurisdiction of the court over the person of the defendant. CIT Rule 4(d)(1).

para.para.text: The above form of waiver must be enclosed with a Notice of Lawsuit and Request for Waiver of Service of Summons. See §22.

Rule 4 of the Rules of the Court of International Trade requires certain parties to cooperate in saving unnecessary costs of service of the summons and complaint. A defendant located in the United States who, after being notified of an action and asked by a plaintiff located in the United States to waive service of a summons, fails to do so will be required to bear the cost of such service unless good cause be shown for the defendant's failure to sign and return the waiver.

It is not good cause for a failure to waive service that a party believes that the complaint is unfounded, or that the court lacks jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action or over the party's person or property. A party who waives service of the summons retains all defenses and objections (except any relating to the summons or to the service of the summons), and may later object to the jurisdiction of the court.

A defendant who waives service of process must within the time specified on the waiver form serve on the plaintiff's attorney or on the unrepresented plaintiff a response to the complaint and must also file a signed copy of the response to the response to the complaint with the court. If the answer or motion is not served within this time, a default judgment may be taken against that defendant. By waiving service of process, a defendant is allowed more time to answer than if the summons had been actually served when the request for waiver of service was received.

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85

form.para.form.text: The following must be printed on the reverse side of the waiver form or set forth at the foot of the form:

form.name.block.name: Duty to Avoid Unnecessary Costs of Service of Summons

form.para.form.text: Rule 4 of the Rules of the Court of International Trade requires certain parties to cooperate in saving unnecessary costs of service of the summons and complaint. A defendant located in the United States who, after being notified of an action and asked by a plaintiff located in the United States to waive service of a summons, fails to do so will be required to bear the cost of such service unless good cause be shown for the defendant's failure to sign and return the waiver.

It is not good cause for a failure to waive service that a party believes that the complaint is unfounded, or that the court lacks jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action or over the party's person or property. A party who waives service of the summons retains all defenses and objections (except any relating to the summons or to the service of the summons), and may later object to the jurisdiction of the court.

A defendant who waives service of process must within the time specified on the waiver form serve on the plaintiff's attorney or on the unrepresented plaintiff a response to the complaint and must also file a signed copy of the response to the response to the complaint with the court. If the answer or motion is not served within this time, a default judgment may be taken against that defendant. By waiving service of process, a defendant is allowed more time to answer than if the summons had been actually served when the request for waiver of service was received.

outline.name.block.name: Proof of service of pleading or other paper

form.para.form.text: [EITHER:]

I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices located at [address of law firm], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [name of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

I, [name of person receiving service], the secretary of [name of attorney], the attorney of record for [name of party], certify that I personally received a copy of [description of pleading or paper] on [date of receipt], at [place of delivery].

statnote.note.text: Papers are served on a party's attorney, if the party is represented by counsel and if the court does not order that service be made on the party personally. Service need only be made on one attorney of record for a party. The papers must be either mailed or delivered to the party or attorney. CIT Rule 5(b).

Delivery is accomplished by handing a copy of the document to the attorney or to the party, or by leaving a copy at the attorney's or party's office. If a copy is left in the office, it must be left with the office clerk or other person in charge, and if there is no one in charge, it must be left in a conspicuous place. If the office is closed or if the person to be served has no office, the document may be left at the recipient's house or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing at that location. CIT Rule 5(b). See also the Practice Comment to CIT Rule 5.

Service by mail is accomplished by mailing the document to the attorney or party at his or her last-known address. If no address is known, the document may be left with the clerk of the court. Service by mail is complete upon mailing. CIT Rule 5(b).
Service of documents by facsimile (FAX) transmission may be made with the consent of the party to be served. See the Practice Comment to CIT Rule 5.

Proof of service is required unless prescribed otherwise by the CIT Rules or by court order. Proof may consist either of an acknowledgment of service by the person served, or a certificate of service by the person serving the paper, stating the date and manner of service and the name of the person served. Proof of service may appear on the paper being filed, or be affixed to that paper. However, for good cause shown, the clerk may permit the filing of papers without proof of service, but the clerk will require that proof be filed promptly thereafter. CIT Rule 5(g).

para.para.text: This subdivision consists of forms of complaints and material related to pleadings in the Court of International Trade and to motions directed to the pleadings.

The CIT Rules authorize the filing of a complaint, an answer, a reply to a counterclaim, answers to cross claims, third-party complaints, and answers to third-party complaints. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:301.

The filing of a complaint is generally required when the action is commenced, or as a means of taking a case off the Reserve Calendar or the Suspension Disposition Calendar and to avoid a dismissal for lack of prosecution, unless the case may be determined on a submission of agreed facts or the like. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:302.

A complaint must generally contain: (1) a short and plain statement of the grounds on which the court's jurisdiction depends, unless the court already has jurisdiction and the claim need show no new ground of jurisdiction to support it; (2) a short and plain statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief; and (3) a demand for judgment. Each averment must be simple, concise, and direct, and no technical forms of pleading are required. The requirement of conciseness is met if the plaintiff briefly states his or her basic claim, and there is no requirement that the complaint state the elements of proof or the entire case which the plaintiff desires to present. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:303.

Although the Appendix of Forms to the CIT Rules does not contain official forms of complaints, its preface indicates what allegations should be included in complaints filed in actions under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(a) challenging the denial of a protest, and in actions filed under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b) contesting a determination on an appraisal, classification, or rate of duty petition. Those allegations are set forth in the Checklist at §33.

Claims may be joined, inconsistent and hypothetical claims may be pleaded, and successive and alternative relief may be requested, so long as grounds exist to support the claims. The complaint will be construed as to do substantial justice. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:303.
Defenses to a complaint are raised by an answer. However, the defendant may raise by motion the defenses of:
lack of subject matter jurisdiction;
lack of personal jurisdiction;
insufficiency of process;
insufficiency of service of the summons and complaint;
failure to state a claim on which relief can be granted; and
failure to join a party whose presence is required for the just adjudication of the claim.5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:307.

As a general rule, a private defendant must serve an answer within 20 days after service of the complaint. Federal defendants have 60 days to answer after service of the complaint. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:308.

An application to the court for an order must be by motion. Unless made during a hearing or trial, a motion must be in writing and must state, with particularity, the grounds for the motion. The motion must set forth the relief or order sought, and must be accompanied by a proposed order. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. &dblsect;37:348, 37:351.
Motions are papers which must be served in accordance with the CIT Rules. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:352.
Every pleading filed with the Court of International Trade must contain a caption which sets forth:
the name of the Court of International Trade;
the title of the action;
the court number; and
the designation of the pleading as a complaint, answer, reply, and the like.9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:334.

Every pleading or other paper of a party represented by an attorney must be signed by at least one attorney of record for that party. The signature must be of the individual attorney, who must also state his or her address and telephone number. A party who is not represented by an attorney must sign his or her own pleadings and state the party's address and telephone number. 10West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:337.

Every pleading or other paper filed on behalf of the United States must be signed by an attorney authorized to do so on behalf of the Assistant Attorney General, Civil Division, Department of Justice, and a pleading or other paper filed on behalf of an agency authorized by statute to represent itself in judicial proceedings may be signed by an attorney authorized to do so on behalf of the agency. 11West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:337.

Every pleading or other paper must be served on each of the parties to an action in the Court of International Trade, unless the CIT Rules or a court order prescribe otherwise. 12West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:339.
As to proof of service, see the discussion following the form in §30).

outline.name.block.name: ChecklistDrafting complaint in particular civil actions in Court of International Trade

para.para.text: Checklist of matters, inter alia, that should be alleged in complaint in particular civil actions in Court of International Trade:
As to all complaints:
Statement of the basis of the court's jurisdiction.
Statement of the plaintiff's standing.
Statement that the protest was timely filed.
Statement, when appropriate, that all liquidated: duties have been paid.
Description of the merchandise involved.
Specification of the contested Customs decision or decisions.
Demand for judgment for the appropriate relief.
If a contested Customs decision involves the value of merchandise, the complaint must also state:
The date and country of exportation.
The appraised value or values.
The claimed statutory basis or bases of value.
The amount or amounts of the unit value claimed to be the correct value or values, or a statement of how the claimed value may be computed.
Concise allegations of the plaintiff's contentions of fact and law which support the preceding allegations.
If the contested Customs decision involves the classification of merchandise, a complaint must also set forth:

The item number of the Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), or the heading or subheading of the Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States, including all modifications and amendments, under which the merchandise was classified, and the rate of duty imposed.

The tariff description and the item number of the Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), or the heading or subheading of the Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States, including all modifications and amendments, under which the merchandise is claimed to be properly subject to classification, and the rate of duty claimed to be applicable.
Concise allegations of plaintiff's contentions of fact and law which support the above claims.
If the contested Customs decision involves any other administrative decision, the complaint must also set forth:
A statement of the nature of the alleged error in the decision.
Concise allegations of plaintiff's contentions of fact and law which support the plaintiff's position.

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:
Plaintiff is the importer of record and ultimate consignee of the merchandise covered by the summons and this complaint.
The [number of entries] involved in this matter were liquidated: on [date of liquidation].
The [number of entries] involved were the subject of protests that were filed with the Regional Commissioner of Customs at the port of New York on [date of filing protests].

The [number of protests] involved were automatically denied by law 30 days after a request Dated: [date of request], addressed to the Regional Commissioner of Customs in New York was made for an accelerated disposition of the protests.
All liquidated: duties covering the [number of entries] have been paid.
The merchandise involved consists of [description of imports].
This merchandise was assessed for duty under Item [number of item] Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), at [description of basis for tariff] as [description of import classification].

form.text.inline.instr: [Statement of nature of alleged error in customs decision.]

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff contends that the [description of imports] involved are properly dutiable at [percentage rate]% ad valorem and [number of cents] per pound under Item [number of item] TSUS as [description of classification].

Plaintiff is entitled to have such merchandise classified [statement of desired classification] at [percentage rate]% ad valorem and [number of cents] per pound under Item [number of item] TSUS because [statement supporting contentions of fact and law].

WHEREFORE, plaintiff requests a judgment directing the District Director of Customs at the port of New York to reliquidate the [number of entries] involved in this matter under Item [number of item] TSUS, at [percentage rate]% ad valorem and [number of cents] per pound, and such other and further relief as the Court deems to be just.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

para.para.text: The complaint must be paginated at the bottom portion, beginning with page 1 [CIT Rule 81(d), (f)] and bound or attached at the top margin [CIT Rule 81(f)]. A copy of the complaint must be served on the opposite party [CIT Rule 4] and duplicate copies filed with the court [CIT Rule 81]. The original must be designated as such [CIT Rule 81(e)].

The above complaint is adapted from the complaint filed in Green Giant Co. v. U. S., 70 Cust. Ct. 20, 355 F. Supp. 1397 (Cust. Ct. 1973), judgment rev'd, 495 F.2d 775 (C.C.P.A. 1974), in which the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals reversed the Customs Court (predecessor of Court of International Trade) and granted the protests.

In cases involving classification, the plaintiff has the dual burden of negating the District Director's classification and establishing the proper classification. Green Giant Co. v. U. S., 495 F.2d 775 (C.C.P.A. 1974).

form.name.block.name: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

entry.ital: action, as applicable, including name of

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:
Plaintiff is a duly licensed customs broker and the importer of record for the merchandise under protest.

Plaintiff, as customs broker for [name of owner of imports], of [address of plaintiff], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state], made entry at [name of port] Entry No. [number of entry] on [date of entry], which entry was liquidated: on [date of liquidation].
On [date of protest], plaintiff filed the protest in this action with the District Director of Customs at the port of [name of port] against the liquidation of the entry in question.
All liquidated: duties have been paid.

The merchandise described on the invoices as receivers, with or without other words of description, was assessed with duty at 15% ad valorem under Item 684.70, Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), reading as follows: [statement of TSUS item verbatim].
Plaintiff claims that the merchandise is dutiable at 12% ad valorem under Item 709.50, TSUS, reading as follows: [statement of TSUS item verbatim].

The articles under protest belong to a class or kind of articles which, at, and immediately prior to the date of importation, were used as parts of hearing aids, which use exceeded all other uses (if any) combined.

The articles under protest are not microphones, loud speakers, headphones, audio-frequency electric amplifiers, electric sound amplifier sets comprised of the foregoing components, or parts of any of the foregoing, or microphones stands, within the meaning and intent of Item 684.70, TSUS.

Headnote 10(ij) (TSUS) provides that a provision for "parts" of an article covers a product solely or chiefly used as a part of that article, but does not prevail over a specific provision for that part.
There is no specific provision for receivers of the kind involved in this case.
The receivers involved in this case are electrical instruments or apparatus.

Even if the articles under protest are described in Item 684.70, they are excluded from Part 5 of schedule 6, TSUS, by reason of Headnote 1(vi) of Part 5, which headnote provides that Part 5 does not cover electrical instruments and apparatus provided for in Schedule 7.
WHEREFORE, plaintiff requests judgment sustaining the protest and directing the District Director of Customs at [description of District] to reliquidate the entry and make refund accordingly.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

The above complaint is adapted from the complaints filed in Knowles Electronics v. U. S., 71 Cust. Ct. 112, 371 F. Supp. 1393 (Cust. Ct. 1973), judgment aff'd, 504 F.2d 1403 (C.C.P.A. 1974), a consolidated: trial, in which defendant in its answer conceded that the receivers in question were properly dutiable as parts of hearing aids under Item 709.50 (hearing aids and parts thereof), and the protest as to the receivers was therefore sustained.

outline.name.block.name: ComplaintProtest of improper classification of importBeads exported to have coating placed on them and then returned to United States as constituting altered goods rather than new articles

form.name.block.name: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

entry.ital: action, as applicable, including name of
judge, if assigned; see Court of International

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:
Plaintiff is the importer of the merchandise at issue, which consists of and was invoiced as glass beads.
The liquidation of Entry No. [number of entry], the subject of the instant protest, occurred on [date of liquidation].
Plaintiff duly made protest on [date of protest] to the Regional Commissioner of Customs at the port of New York.
All liquidated: duties assessed on the involved entry have been paid.

The merchandise at issue was classified as "beads, bugles, and spangles (except natural, cultured, or imitation pearls), not strung (except temporarily) and not set: other," under Item 741.30, Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), at the rate of [percentage rate]% ad valorem.

The nature of the error in the above-mentioned assessment is that the merchandise at issue is not properly dutiable as classified. The proper classification of the merchandise is: "Articles returned to the United States after having been exported to be advanced in value or improved in condition by any process of manufacture or other means: articles exported for repairs or alterations," under Item 806.20, TSUS. Item 741.30, under which Customs classified the beads at a rate of 14% ad valorem, is applicable solely to the invoiced cost of the alteration, [description of cost]. The balance of the merchandise invoiced at a value of [description of value] is entitled to free entry under Item 806.20.

The merchandise was exported from the United States by plaintiff on [date of export] to [name of foreign country], solely for the purpose of having placed on it a half-coating imparting to the beads an Aurora Borealis finish.
While abroad, the merchandise was, in fact, half-coated, as set forth in paragraph 7.
The merchandise was returned to the United States and imported under New York Entry No. [number of entry] on [date of importation].
The application of the Aurora Borealis finish did not change the character, identity, or use of the imported merchandise in the United States from that of the exported merchandise.
All customs regulations pertaining to the entry of merchandise under Item 806.20, TSUS, have been complied with.

The application of the Aurora Borealis finish comes within the common meaning ascribed to "repairs or alterations" under Item 806.20, TSUS, under 19 C.F.R. §10.8(a), and under judicial precedents established by this Court. [Citation of authorities].

WHEREFORE, plaintiff respectfully requests that the protest be sustained and that the costs of the instant alteration, in the amount of $[dollar amount], be held dutiable at the rate of 14% ad valorem, under Item 741.30, by virtue of Item 806.20, and that the value of the glass beads, $[dollar amount], be held free of duty under Item 806.20.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

statnote.note.text: The complaint must be paginated at the bottom portion, beginning with page 1 [CIT Rule 81(d), (f)] and bound or attached at the top margin [CIT Rule 81(f)]. A copy of the complaint must be served on the opposite party [CIT Rule 4] and duplicate copies filed with the court [CIT Rule 81]. The original must be designated as such [CIT Rule 81(e)].

para.para.text: The above complaint is adapted from the complaint filed in Royal Bead Novelty Co. v. U. S., 68 Cust. Ct. 154, 342 F. Supp. 1394 (Cust. Ct. 1972), where it was held that plaintiff had overcome the presumption of correctness attaching to the classification and had established that the application of the Aurora Borealis finish neither destroyed the identity of the exported beads nor created a new or different article, but constituted an "alteration" within the intendment of Item 806.20, TSUS, and 19 C.F.R. §10.8. The merchandise was held subject to duty solely on the value of the alterations at the rate that would apply to the article itself, in its condition as imported, if it were not within the purview of Item 806.20 and 19 C.F.R. §10.8.

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:
Plaintiff is the importer of record on the entries involved in this matter.
The subject entries were liquidated: on the dates indicated in the attached schedule.
The protests were filed with the Regional Commissioner of Customs at New York on the dates indicated in the attached schedule.
All liquidated: duties have been paid.

The Customs decisions complained of are the classification of the imported battery chargers under Item 682.60, Tariff Schedules of the United States (TSUS), as modified by Pres. Proc. 3822, and the assessment of duty on them at the rate of [description of rate] or [percentage rate]% ad valorem, depending on the date of entry.

The error alleged to exist in the above Customs decisions is the failure to classify the imported merchandise under Item 688.40, TSUS, as modified by Pres. Proc. 3822, and to assess duty under same at the rate of [description of rate] or [percentage rate]% ad valorem, depending on the date of entry.
Item 682.60, TSUS, provides as follows: [statement of pertinent part verbatim].
Item 688.40, TSUS, provides as follows: "Electrical articles, and electrical parts of articles, not specifically provided for."
The specific articles that are the subjects of this complaint are [name] battery chargers.
The battery chargers are designed and intended to be used to test 1.5 and 9 volt batteries to determine if they should be recharged and to what extent.
The battery chargers are also designed and intended to be used to recharge 1.5 and 9 volt batteries.

form.text.inline.instr: [Statement of other allegations showing the battery chargers have more and different functions than provided for in the Item under which classified.]

form.para.form.text: The merchandise is not a generator, a motor-generator, a convertor, a rectifier, a rectifying apparatus, nor inductors, within the purview of Item 682.60, TSUS.
By design, function, and use, the battery chargers perform more and different functions than the articles enumerated within Item 682.60, TSUS.
The battery chargers are more than any of the articles referred to in paragraph 13.
The battery chargers are electrical articles within Item 688.40, TSUS.
The battery chargers are not more specifically provided for in any provisions other than Item 688.40, TSUS.

WHEREFORE, plaintiff requests judgment sustaining the protest and holding that the described imported merchandise should be classified under Item 688.40, TSUS, and assessed with a duty as indicated in paragraph 6.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

para.para.text: The complaint must be paginated at the bottom portion, beginning with page 1 [CIT Rule 81(d), (f)] and bound or attached at the top margin [CIT Rule 81(f)]. A copy of the complaint must be served on the opposite party [CIT Rule 4] and duplicate copies filed with the court [CIT Rule 81]. The original must be designated as such [CIT Rule 81(e)].

The complaint set forth above is adapted from the complaint filed in Fedtro, Inc. v. U. S., 72 Cust. Ct. 267, 376 F. Supp. 1398 (Cust. Ct. 1974), in which the court held that the import in question, a multi-purpose battery charger, had more features than, and was therefore "more than," a rectifying apparatus, in which classification it had been placed by Customs.

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:

Plaintiff is the owner and ultimate consignee of the merchandise covered by the summons and this complaint and [name of importer], a custom house broker, of [address of broker], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state], is the importer of record of the merchandise on behalf of plaintiff.
The appraisement entry involved in this matter was liquidated: on [date of liquidation].
The appraisement entry was the subject of a protest that was filed with the District Director of Customs at the port of [description of port] on [date of protest].
The protest was denied by the District Director of Customs at the port of [description of port] on [date of denial].
All the liquidated: duties covered by the entry involved in this matter have been paid.
The merchandise involved in this proceeding consists of a [description of yacht] named [name of yacht], registered in [name of foreign country].

This yacht was assessed for duty as a yacht or pleasure boat regardless of length or tonnage, valued over $[dollar amount], whether motor, sail or steam propelled, owned by a resident of the United States or brought into the United States for sale or charter to a resident, whether or not the yacht was brought into the United States under its own power, at the rate of five percent ad valorem under Item 696.10, TSUS as modified by Pres. Proc. 3822.
Plaintiff contends that the yacht in question is a non-importation as there was no intent that the yacht remain permanently in this country.
The yacht [name of yacht] was built in [name of foreign country] and completed on [date of completion].
The [name of yacht] was designed and built for charter in the Mediterranean, which requires over-the-stern gangway for Mediterranean-style mooring and 220 volt shore power connection.
During its shakedown cruise across the Atlantic, paint on the hull of the yacht started to chip and crack, and it was brought into [name of city], [name of state] for repairs.
On entering the territorial waters of the United States, the yacht was granted a cruising license provided for under Section 4.94 of the Customs Regulations.
After repairs were made to it, the yacht departed for Hawaii, still under the cruising license, which was renewed in Hawaii.

Prior to the expiration of the renewed cruising license, the yacht departed Hawaii and is at present employed as a charter vessel in the Mediterranean and was never intended as a permanent importation into the United States.
The yacht was not brought into the United States for sale or charter to any resident of the United States.

WHEREFORE, plaintiff requests judgment directing the District Director at the port of [description of port] to reliquidate the appraisement entry involved free of duty as a nonimportation, and for such other and further relief as the Court deems just.

Ct. 1974), in which the court found that a yacht was not imported into the United States where there was no intent permanently to bring it into the United States and where the yacht was brought to the United States only temporarily for repairs and as part of a general shakedown cruise which was intended to, and did, in fact, end in the Mediterranean where the yacht was to be used in the future.
