form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], appears by and through its counsel and for its claim against defendant, the United States, alleges the following:
Plaintiff is the importer of record of the merchandise covered by [name of port] entry No. [number of entry] entered on [date of entry].
The entry was appraised on [date of appraisal], and notice of appraisement was issued on [date of issuance].
Protest No. [number of protest] was filed by the attorney for plaintiff with the District Director of Customs at the port of [description of port] on [date of filing].
The merchandise covered by the entry consists of and is described on the special Customs invoice as [description of merchandise].
The merchandise was exported from [name of foreign country] on [date of export].
The merchandise was appraised at U.S. $[dollar amount] per [description of unit].
On information and belief, the merchandise was appraised by the Customs Service under Section 402(d), Tariff Act of 1930, as amended, on the basis of constructed value.

On information and belief, the appraisement was made by adding amounts for royalty and trademark certification payments totaling [number of cents]to the entered unit value of U.S. $[dollar amount] per [description of unit].
The appraisement is in error, in that charges for royalty and trademark certification payments are not part of the dutiable value of the subject merchandise.

The merchandise was properly appraised under Section 402(d) of the Tariff Act of 1930, as amended, on the basis of constructed value, there being no export value or United States value as defined in Sections 402(b) and 402(c), Tariff Act of 1930, as amended]. However the amounts for royalty and trademark certification payments should not have been added as part of the constructed value.
The merchandise should have been appraised at U.S. $[dollar amount] per [description of unit].
The merchandise and the parties are the same as in [Court of International Trade or other appropriate citation].
The issues involved in this case are the same in all material respects to the issues in [Court of International Trade or other appropriate citation as in paragraph 12].

WHEREFORE, plaintiff requests the court to sustain the protest, render judgment for plaintiff, find the appraised value to be $[dollar amount] per [description of unit], on the basis of constructed value, Section [402(d), Tariff Act of 1930, as amended], and grant such other and further relief as the court may deem appropriate.

Ct. 1972), judgment aff'd, 505 F.2d 721 (C.C.P.A. 1974), in which the court held that where the issues, merchandise, and parties were the same as in a prior case the doctrine of collateral estoppel applied and that royalty and trademark certification payments did not properly constitute part of constructed value.

statnote.note.text: A party may move for a more definite statement before filing a responsive pleading if the complaint is so vague or ambiguous that the movant cannot reasonably be required to frame an answer. CIT Rule 12(e).

A motion for a more definite statement must point out the defects in the complaint and the details desired. If the motion is granted and the particulars are not provided within 10 days after notice of the court's quarter, or within such other time fixed by the court, the court may strike the complaint or make such other order as it deems just. CIT Rule 12(e).

para.para.text: The defendant should request a more definite statement if the plaintiff's allegations are not clear, but they may be construed in such a manner that they may survive a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:318.

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, by its attorney and pursuant to Rule 12(c) of the Rules of the Court of International Trade, moves the Court to enter a judgment on the pleadings in plaintiff's favor on the grounds that there are no disputed facts and that it appears from the factual allegations contained in the pleadings that plaintiff is entitled to a judgment awarding it the relief claimed in its complaint.
This motion is based on [description of pleadings] on file and on the [brief or memorandum of points and authorities] attached.

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

para.para.text: After the pleadings are closed but within such time as not to delay the trial, any party may move for judgment on the pleadings. If, on a motion for judgment on the pleadings, matters outside the pleadings are presented to and not excluded by the court, the motion must be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as provided in CIT Rule 56, and all parties must be given reasonable opportunity to present all material made pertinent to such a motion by CIT Rule 56. CIT Rule 12(c).

statnote.note.text: If a motion for judgment on the pleadings is accompanied by matters outside the pleadings which are not excluded by the court, the motion will be treated as one for summary judgment. The parties must be given a reasonable opportunity to present materials pertinent to a motion for summary judgment before the court may determine the motion. CIT Rule 12(c).

para.para.text: When a motion is directed solely to the pleadings, the movant admits the truth of his or her adversary's well-pleaded factual allegations, but denies their sufficiency as a matter of law. For the movant to be entitled to a judgment on the pleadings, it must appear certain that the opposing party is entitled to no relief under any state of facts that could be proved in support of the opposing party's claim or allegations. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:316.

para.para.text: This subdivision contains forms and material pertaining to dismissal of actions in the Court of International Trade.

Subject to the CIT Rules governing the compromise of a class action and the conduct of a receivership, and subject to any applicable statute of the United States, a plaintiff may voluntarily dismiss an action pending in the Court of International Trade by (a) filing a notice of dismissal at any time before the adverse party serves an answer or a motion for summary judgment, whichever occurs first, or (b) filing a stipulation of dismissal, signed by all parties who have appeared in the action. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:523.

Counterclaims, cross claims, and third-party claims may be dismissed in the manner described above. The claimant in those cases may seek a voluntary dismissal before a responsive pleading is served, and if no responsive pleading is served, before the introduction of evidence at the trial or hearing.2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:523.

The first voluntary dismissal of an action by notice or stipulation is without prejudice, unless the notice or stipulation states otherwise, but a notice of dismissal is an adjudication of the merits of the claim if the same plaintiff has previously asked that any federal or state court dismiss an action based on or which included the same claims presented in the present action. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:523.

If the conditions on the voluntary dismissal of an action described above cannot be met, a plaintiff may only seek the dismissal of the action by court order, which may be made on such terms and conditions as the court deems proper. This requirement also applies to voluntary dismissals sought by counterclaimants, cross claimants, and third-party claimants. If a defendant pleads a counterclaim prior to the service of the plaintiff's motion to dismiss, the action will not be dismissed over the defendant's objection unless the counterclaim can remain pending for an independent adjudication by the court. A voluntary dismissal pursuant to court order is without prejudice, unless the order specifies otherwise.4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:524.

Involuntary dismissals are ordered by the court when a plaintiff or other claimant fails to prosecute a case with due diligence, or fails to comply with the CIT Rules or a court order. For instance, a dismissal for lack of prosecution may be based on a failure to present proof and argue contentions in a brief.5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:525.

A dismissal for lack of prosecution may be made on court order, either on the court's own initiative after notice, or on a defendant's motion. A defendant may move to have an action dismissed for the plaintiff's failure to comply with the rules or a court order. An involuntary dismissal operates as a dismissal on the merits, unless the court directs otherwise.6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:525.

outline.name.block.name: Opposition to motion to dismissOwner and actual importer of merchandise proper party to file protest

form.name.block.name: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

entry.ital: action, as applicable, including name of
judge, if assigned; see Court of International

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, [name of plaintiff], opposes defendant's motion to dismiss and as grounds for such opposition alleges:
The subject merchandise, [description of imports], was imported through the port of [description of port], on [date of importation].

Entries were filed by [name of broker], a customhouse broker in [name of city], for the account of plaintiff, as shown by the consumption entry form (Customs Form 7501) attached as Exhibit [designation of exhibit].
Plaintiff was the actual purchaser of the merchandise, as shown by the commercial and special Customs invoices attached as Exhibits [designation of exhibits].

The "Carrier's Certificate and Release Order" (Customs Form 7529), attached as Exhibit [designation of exhibit], in each entry certifies that [name of customhouse broker] is the owner or consignee of those articles within the purview of Section 484(h) of the Tariff Act of 1930.

Protest No. [number of protest] was signed by plaintiff's counsel on behalf of plaintiff and [name of customhouse broker] on [date of signing]. A copy of the protest is attached as Exhibit [designation of exhibit].

Defendant urges that the protest be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction on the ground that the entries were made by [name of customhouse broker], the importer of record, while the protest was filed by plaintiff, whom defendant alleges was neither the "importer" nor the "consignee" for tariff purposes.

Under Section 514(b) of the Tariff Act of 1930, the party filing a protest must be "the importer, consignee, or any authorized agent of the person paying any charge or exaction, or filing any claim for drawback, or seeking entry or delivery."

For the purposes of Section 514, a protest may be filed by a person who proves that such person is the real party in interest or his or her agent, as is more fully shown by the memorandum of citations attached as Exhibit [designation of exhibit].

Plaintiff has standing to file the protest as the actual owner and importer of the merchandise. The courts have recognized the purchaser and actual owner of the importations as a party authorized to file protests, as is more fully shown by the above-mentioned attached memorandum.

The protests were signed by plaintiff's attorney on behalf of [name of customhouse broker] as well as plaintiff, and consequently the protest must be considered as filed by both the nominal and ultimate consignees.

para.para.text: The above form is based on Hancock Gross Mfg., Inc. v. U.S., 75 Cust. Ct. 188, 400 F. Supp. 813 (Cust. Ct. 1975), in which court denied, on the grounds alleged in the form, the United States' motion to dismiss.

The courts have consistently permitted the owner-importer of merchandise or his or her agent to protest the decision of the collector, even though the owner-importer was not so identified in the entry papers, on proof of identity at the trial. See Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:86.

para.para.text: A plaintiff may file a motion to set aside an order of dismissal in order to raise such claims as that a failure to remove a case from the Reserve Calendar was due to excusable neglect. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:293.

Any motion to set aside an order of dismissal must be presented on or before the 30th day after the order dismissing the action is entered, in compliance with 28 U.S.C.A. §2646. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:293.

para.para.text: This subdivision contains forms and material pertaining to discovery (admissions, interrogatories, and inspection), and to the use of depositions, in proceedings in the Court of International Trade.
Other pretrial proceedings are treated in the following subdivision. See &dblsect;134 et seq.

A party may serve on any other party a written request for admissions. These requests may relate to the truth of any matters that are within the general scope of discovery, and may include admissions regarding statements or opinions of fact, of the application of law to the facts, or of the genuineness of any documents described in the request. Each matter on which an admission is requested must be separately set forth, and copies of all documents described in the request must be served with the request, unless they have been or otherwise are furnished or made available for inspection and copying. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:342.

A request may be served on a plaintiff without leave of the court after the complaint is filed, and on any other party at the same time the summons and complaint are served on the party or at any time thereafter. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:432.

A party who receives a request for admissions must serve a written answer or objection to each matter specified in the request, or else that matter will be deemed admitted. This response must be served within 30 days after service of the request, although a longer or shorter time period may be allowed by court order. In addition, a defendant is not required to serve answers or objections before the expiration of 45 days after service of the summons and complaint, unless the court orders a quicker response. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:433.

The answers must specifically deny the substance of each request, or set forth detailed reasons why the answering party cannot truthfully admit or deny the matter. All denials must fairly meet the substance of the requested admission, and if good faith requires that a party qualify an answer or deny only part of a request, the party must description of so much of the request that is true and qualify or deny the remainder. An answering party may not give lack of information or knowledge as a reason for failing to admit or deny, unless the party states that he or she has made reasonable inquiry and the information known or readily attainable is insufficient to enable him or her to admit or deny. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:433

The reasons for all objections must be stated. However, a party may not object on the ground that a request for admissions presents a genuine issue for trial; instead, the party must deny the matter or set forth the reasons why he or she cannot admit or deny it. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:433.
Pursuant to CIT Rule 36(a), all answers or objections must be signed by the party or party's attorney. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:433.

The party who has requested admissions may move to determine the sufficiency of the answers or objections. The court will order that an answer be served if it finds that an objection is not justified. If the court determines that an answer does not comply with the requirements prescribed in the preceding section, it may either order that the matter be deemed admitted or that an amended answer be served. The court also has the option to defer the final disposition of the request for admissions until a pretrial conference or to another designated time prior to trial. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:434.

Any matter admitted pursuant to a request for admissions conclusively established for the purpose of the pending action only, unless the court permits the withdrawal or amendment of the admission on motion. Subject to the rule regarding the amendment of postassignment scheduling or conference orders, the court may permit the withdrawal or amendment of an admission if this will promote the presentation of the case on the merits, and if the party who obtained the admission fails to satisfy the court that the withdrawal or amendment will prejudice the maintenance of his or her action or defense on the merits. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:435.

Any party may serve written interrogatories on any other party, including parties that are organizations, such as corporations, partnerships, associations, and government agencies. Interrogatories may be served on the plaintiff after the complaint is filed, and on any other party at the same time or after the summons and complaint are served on that party. Leave of court is not required in these situations. 9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:425.

While interrogatories that seek opinions are not necessarily objectionable, it is better to seek specific answers and objective factual data. Precision is quite important, since an answer to a vague interrogatory might be responsive, but might not yield the desired information. 10West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:425.

Interrogatories must be answered by the party served and, if the party is a public or private corporation, a partnership, an association, or a government agency, by any officer or agent who must furnish such information as is available to the organizational party. Each interrogatory must be answered separately and fully in writing under oath, unless an objection is made to the question. Reasons for an objection are to be stated in lieu of an answer. An interrogatory is not necessarily rendered objectionable by the fact that it seeks an opinion, a factual contention, or a contention about the application of the law to the facts, that the court may delay the need to answer the interrogatory until after designated discovery has been completed, the postassignment conference, or other later time. Answers are to be signed by the person who answered the interrogatories, and objections are to be signed by the attorney making them. The answers and objections must generally be served within 30 days after the interrogatories were served, but a defendant may serve answers and objections within 45 days after service of the summons and complaint on him or her. A shorter or longer time to respond may be allowed by court order. 11West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:426.
Objections to interrogatories are determined on a motion to compel discovery. 12West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:426.

It is sometime permissible to answer an interrogatory by stating that the answer may be derived or ascertained from specified business records. This option may be used if the answer may be derived from business records, or from an examination, audit, or inspection of the records or of a compilation, abstract, or summary of same, and if the burden of deriving or ascertaining the answer is substantially the same for the party serving the interrogatory as for the party being served. The applicable records must be specified in a sufficiently detailed manner, so that the interrogating party may locate and identify them as readily as the answering party, and, naturally, the interrogating party must be given an opportunity to examine the records. 13West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:426.

Any party to an action in the Court of International Trade may serve on any other party a request to produce and permit the inspection and copying of designated documents, or to permit the inspection, copying, testing, and sampling of tangible things, if the documents or things requested are within the ordinary scope of discovery and are in the possession, custody, or control of the party on whom the request is served. Documents which may be inspected include writing, drawings, graphs, charts, photographs, phonographic records, and other data compilations from which information can be obtained, translated, or otherwise retrieved in reasonably usable form. Such a request may be made of the plaintiff without leave of court after the complaint is filed, and of any other party when or after that party is served with the summons and complaint. A request must set forth the items to be inspected, either individually or by category, and description of each item or category with reasonable particularity, as well as description of a reasonable time, place, and manner of making the inspection and performing related acts. 14West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:429.

A party who receives a request for the production or inspection of documents or tangible things must generally serve a written response within 30 days after the request is served. However, a defendant may serve a response within 45 days after being served with the summons and complaint. These time limits may be modified by court order. 15West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:430.

The response must state, with respect to each item or category, that inspection and related activities will be permitted as requested, or that an objection will be made to disclosure. All objections must description of the part of an item or category that the respondent does not wish to disclose, along with the reason for the objection. The party who made the request for inspection may contest objections to or failure to respond to the request by presenting a motion to compel discovery. Pursuant to CIT Rule 34(b), a party who produces documents for inspection must produce the documents in either the manner they are kept in the usual course of business or organized and labeled in a manner which corresponds to the categories of the request. 16West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:430.

The CIT Rules permit the entry on land or other property for inspection and physical and mental examinations of persons. These discovery rules track parallel provisions of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. 17West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:431.

A deposition may be taken before the commencement of an action in the Court of International Trade in order to perpetuate testimony. A person may perpetuate his or her own testimony or the testimony of another person by deposition. Such a person must file a petition in his or her own name which shows:
that the petitioner expects to be a party in an action cognizable in the Court of International Trade but is currently unable to bring it or cause it to be brought,
the facts that the petitioner desires to establish by the proposed testimony and the reasons why the petitioner desires to perpetuate it;
the names, or a description, of the persons the petitioner expects will be adverse parties, and their addresses so far as are known to the petitioner; and
the names and addresses of the persons to be examined, and the substance of the testimony expected to be elicited from each witness.

Finally, the petitioner must ask for an order authorizing him or her to take the depositions of the persons to be examined and named in the petition for the purpose of perpetuating their testimony, and must verify the petition. 18West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:408.

After filing the petition, the petitioner must serve a notice and a copy of the petition on each person named in the petition as an expected adverse party. The notice must state that the petitioner will apply to the court for the order requested in the petition at the time and place stated in the notice. This notice must be served in the manner provided by CIT Rule 4 for the service of a summons at least 20 days before the date of the hearing, but if service cannot be made with due diligence on any expected adverse party, the court may order service by publication or otherwise. The court will appoint an attorney for persons not served in accordance with CIT Rule 4, and the right of minors or incompetents who are potential adverse parties will be protected in accordance with CIT Rule 17(c). 19West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:408.

The court will make an order designating or describing the persons whose depositions may be taken, a description of the subject matter of the examination, and a description of whether the depositions will be taken on oral examination or written interrogatories, if the court is satisfied that the perpetuation of the testimony may prevent a failure or a delay of justice. The deposition may then be taken in accordance with the CIT Rules, and may be used in any subsequent action involving the same subject matter, in accordance with the general rule on the use of depositions in Court of International Trade proceedings. 20West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:408.

CIT Rule 27(c), relating to the perpetuation of testimony by deposition prior to the filing of an action, does not limit the power of the court to entertain an action to perpetuate testimony. 21West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:408.

The Court of International Trade may allow the taking of depositions to perpetuate testimony for use in the event further proceedings will be necessary in that court after an appeal. This type of deposition may be taken after an appeal is taken from a judgment of the Court of International Trade or before taking an appeal, if the appeal time has not expired. 22West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:409.

A party desiring to perpetuate testimony pending appeal must move in the Court of International Trade for leave to take depositions, after noticing and serving of the motion in the same manner as any other motion presented in a case still pending in that court. The motion must show the names and addresses of the persons to be examined, the substance of the testimony expected from each, and the reasons for perpetuating their testimony. The court will make an appropriate order permitting the deposition if it finds that the perpetuation of testimony is proper to avoid a failure or delay of justice; thereafter the deposition may be taken and used in the same manner and under the same conditions as any other deposition in court proceedings. 23West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:409.

CIT Rule 27(c), regarding perpetuation of testimony pending appeal, does not limit the power of the court to entertain an action to perpetuate testimony. 24West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:409.

Depositions taken within the jurisdiction of the United States must be taken before an officer authorized to administer oaths by the laws of the United States or of the place where the examination is held, or before a person appointed by the court. A person appointed by the court has the power to administer oaths and to take testimony. 25West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:410.

Depositions may be taken in foreign countries: (a) before a person authorized by American or foreign law to administer oaths in the place where the examination is held; (b) before a person commissioned by the court, who has the power by virtue of the commission to administer any necessary oaths and to take testimony; or (c) pursuant to a letter rogatory. 26West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:410.

The parties may stipulate in writing that depositions may be taken before any person at any time or place. However, no deposition may be taken before a person who is a relative, employee, attorney, or counsel of any of the parties, is a relative or employee of a party's attorney or counsel, or is financially interested in the action. 27West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:410.

Commissions and letters rogatory are issued on a motion consisting of an application and notice. The motion must be made in writing after the answer is filed, and must set forth the names and addresses of the witnesses whose testimony is sought. Proposed interrogatories must be annexed to the motion. The movant need not show that the taking of the deposition in any other manner is practicable or inconvenient. 28West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:411.

Commissions or letters rogatory only issue on court order, subject to terms that the court finds just and appropriate. Both a commission and a letter rogatory may be issued in proper cases, and these documents will be issued in the name of the President of the United States and under the seal of the court. 29West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:411.

A party who desires to take the deposition of any person on oral examination must give reasonable notice in writing to every other party in the action. The notice must state the time and place for taking the deposition and the name and address of each person to be examined, if known. If the name of the deponent is not known, a general description is required which is sufficient to identify the deponent or the particular class or group to which the deponent belongs. If a subpoena duces tecum is to served on the person to be examined, the notice must also description of materials which must be produced in accordance with the subpoena. A notice to a party deponent may be accompanied by a request for the production of documents and tangible things, in which case a subpoena is not required. A shorter or longer time for taking a deposition than that specified in the notice of deposition may be permitted by court order. 30West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:413.
Under CIT Rule 32(c)(1), all errors and irregularities in the notice of deposition are waived unless a written objection is promptly served on the party giving the notice.

A party desiring to take a deposition on written questions must serve the questions on every other party along with a notice which states: (1) the name and address of the person who is to answer the questions if known, or a general description sufficient to identify the deponent or the particular class or group to which he or she belongs if the deponent's name is not known; and (2) the name, or descriptive title, and address of the officer before whom the deposition is to be taken. Within 30 days after the notice and written questions are served, a party may serve cross questions upon all other parties. Redirect questions may be served within 10 days after the cross questions, and recross questions may be served 10 days after the redirect questions. The court may, for good cause, order a longer time for completing this process. 31West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:414.

Under CIT Rule 32(c)(3)(C), objections to the form of written questions are waived unless they are served in writing on the party propounding the questions within the time allowed for serving the succeeding questions, or within five days after service of the last questions authorized by CIT Rule 31.

para.para.text: A party may apply for an order compelling discovery by presenting a motion on reasonable notice to the other parties. [CIT Rule 37(a)] The moving party must consult with opposing counsel before presenting the motion, and attempt to resolve the problem. [CIT Rule 7(b)] If consultation is not successful, the party should present a motion, which basically requests that the court order that a person answer a deposition question, answer an interrogatory, or permit inspection in accordance with a request, or that an organization served with a deposition notice or subpoena designate a person to appear at the deposition on its behalf. [CIT Rule 37(a)(1)] A motion may also be provoked by an evasive or incomplete answer, which will be treated as a failure to answer. [CIT Rule 37(a)(2)].
As to the award of expenses of a motion under CIT Rule 37, see CIT Rule 37(a)(3).

form.para.form.text: Motion is made by [name of attorney], attorney for plaintiff, pursuant to Rule 37(a) of the Rules of this Court, for an ordering compelling defendant to produce all Customs Laboratory work notes, written data, and computations pertaining to New York Customs Laboratory Report No. [number of report] on the ground that defendant has failed to permit the inspection and copying of matter, not privileged, which is relevant to the subject matter involved in the pending action, and which is in the possession, custody, and control of defendant, as requested by plaintiff pursuant to Rule 34 of the Rules of this Court, as is more particularly shown in the attached memorandum in support of this motion, and for such other relief as to the Court may seem just and proper.

Ct. 1972), in which the Customs Laboratory work notes, written work data, and computations pertaining to a relevant Customs Laboratory Report were held not privileged and were required to be produced for inspection and copying.

name.block.name: MEMORANDUM IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFF'S MOTION TO COMPEL INSPECTION

form.para.form.text: Pursuant to Rule 34 of the Rules of the United States Court of International Trade, the plaintiff, by its attorneys [list of names of attorneys], on [date of service], served on defendant and defendant's attorney, [name of attorney], a Request for the production of certain documents and samples. In that Request the plaintiff asks, in part, that the defendant produce, for the purposes of inspecting, copying and/or testing the following materials: [description of materials:

form.text.inline.instr: The Government's retained copy of New York Customs Laboratory Report No. [number of report] dealing with merchandise taken from entry [description of entry] on [date of entry];
All Customs Laboratory work notes, written work data, and computations pertaining to New York Customs Laboratory Report No. [number of report];

form.para.form.text: A sufficient part of the sample or samples used for New York Customs Laboratory Report No. [number of report] so that the same may be tested by an independent laboratory designated by the plaintiff].

On [date of receipt], the plaintiff received the Government's "response to request" which acceded to requests (a) and (c), but refused to make available the material requested in (b) on the grounds that the requested materials constitute inter-agency memoranda which are exempt from disclosure under 5 U.S.C.A. §552(b)(5).

name.block.name: THE REQUESTED MATTER IS RELEVANT AND NOT PRIVILEGED

form.para.form.text: Under Rule 26(b) of the Rules of this Court, discovery is permitted in connection with "any matter, not privileged, which is relevant to the subject matter involved in the pending action."

The Government denied plaintiff its right to obtain laboratory work notes, written work data, and computations which pertain to the very same laboratory report which it intends to furnish as a result of discovery proceedings. The defendant does not allege that the work notes, work data, and computations are not relevant to the instant action, but rather, it contends that these materials are exempt from disclosure under 5 U.S.C.A. §552(b)(5). The plaintiff notes that defendant has not alleged that the requested material is "privileged" as is required by Rule 26(b). In other words, even if for the moment we assume, arguendo, that the subject materials are within the scope of 5 U.S.C.A. §552(b)(5), that is not to say that it constitutes privileged material that is beyond the reach of the United States Court of International Trade.
In summary, the plaintiff submits that the defendant has refused to furnish properly requested "documents and things" which are relevant matters and which are not privileged.
WHEREFORE, the plaintiff respectfully requests that its motion to compel production be granted.

outline.name.block.name: ComplaintProtest of exclusion of merchandise from entry by Bureau of Customs and Border Protection

caption.block.form.line: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

form.para.form.text: [Plaintiff brings/Plaintiffs bring] this action to contest the denial by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection of a protest under 28 U.S.C.A. §2631. This Court, therefore, has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(a).

[Plaintiff is/Plaintiffs are] the [person/persons] who filed surety on the transaction that is the subject of the protest the denial of which is being contested by this action. Therefore, [plaintiff has/plaintiffs have] standing to bring this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §2631(a).
The protest at issue was timely filed on [date protest was filed].
The merchandise excluded from entry is [description of merchandise].
[Description of decision by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection to exclude merchandise].
[Plaintiff/Plaintiffs] filed a protest to the decision to exclude the merchandise described above on [date of filing of protest]. [Summary of administrative proceedings, including denial of protest].

[Plaintiff's/Plaintiffs'] protest was wrongfully denied because the merchandise described above is entitled to entry. The merchandise is entitled to entry because [concise allegations of fact and law in support of position].
WHEREFORE, [plaintiff requests/plaintiffs request] that this Court enter an order requiring the port director to permit entry of the above-described merchandise.
Dated: [date of complaint]

para.para.text: A complaint filed under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(a) challenging the denial of a protest should set forth: (1) a statement of the basis of the court's jurisdiction; (2) a statement of the plaintiff's standing; (3) a statement that the protest was timely filed; (4) a statement that all liquidated duties have been paid, when appropriate; (5) a description of the merchandise involved; (6) a specification of the contested decision or decisions by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection; and (7) a demand for judgment for the appropriate relief (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (a)). If the complaint involves certain protested decisions, such as the decision to exclude merchandise from entry, the complaint should also set forth a statement of the nature of the alleged error in the decision, and concise allegations of the plaintiff's contentions of fact and law in support of the plaintiff's position (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (d)).
A copy of the complaint must be served on each other party to the action and filed with the Court. CIT Rule 5(a), 5(d).

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 84(9)

reference.entry.ref.text: Appeal of denial of protest of customs exclusion of merchandise. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;192 to 204, 250 to 319

outline.name.block.name: ComplaintContesting denial by Bureau of Customs and Border Protection of petition challenging valuation decision

caption.block.form.line: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

form.para.form.text: [Plaintiff brings/Plaintiffs bring] this action to contest the denial by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection of a petition challenging a valuation decision under 28 U.S.C.A. §2631. This Court, therefore, has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b).

[Plaintiff is/Plaintiffs are] the [person/persons] who filed the petition challenging the valuation decision. Therefore, [plaintiff has/plaintiffs have] standing to bring this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §2631(b).
The merchandise subject to valuation is [description of merchandise]. Such merchandise was imported from [name of country of exportation] on [date of exportation].

form.text.inline.instr: [OPTIONAL: All liquidated duties for the merchandise were paid on [date duties paid].]

form.para.form.text: On [date request was filed], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] filed a written request for information as to the appraised value of the merchandise in question with the Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection. On [date of receipt of valuation by Commissioner], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] received a response indicating [statement of appraised value or values].

On [date of filing of petition], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] timely filed a petition indicating [his/her/its/their] belief that [statement of amount or amounts of unit value claimed to be correct value or values, or of how claimed value should be computed]. By notice dated [date of notice], the Commissioner informed [plaintiff/plaintiffs] that [his/her] original valuation was correct, citing [statutory basis or bases of value].

[Plaintiff renews/Plaintiffs renew] [his/her/its/their] contention that [statement of amount or amounts of unit value claimed to be correct value or values, or of how claimed value should be computed]. [Concise allegations of fact and law in support of contentions].

WHEREFORE, [plaintiff requests/plaintiffs request] that this Court enter an order directing the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection to appraise the merchandise in question in accordance with the [value/methodology] as set forth by [plaintiff/plaintiffs] in paragraph 7, above.
Dated: [date of complaint]

para.para.text: A complaint filed under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b) contesting the denial of an interested party's challenge to a valuation, classification, or rate of duty determination should set forth: (1) a statement of the basis of the court's jurisdiction; (2) a statement of the plaintiff's standing; (3) a statement that the protest was timely filed; (4) a statement that all liquidated duties have been paid, when appropriate; (5) a description of the merchandise involved; (6) a specification of the contested decision or decisions by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection; and (7) a demand for judgment for the appropriate relief (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (a)). If the contested customs decision involves the value of merchandise, the complaint should also set forth the date and country of exportation; a statement of the appraised value or values; a statement of the claimed statutory basis or bases of value; a statement of the amount or amounts of the unit value claimed to be the correct value or values, or a statement of how the claimed value may be computed; and concise allegations of plaintiff's contentions of fact and law in support of the above (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (b)).
A copy of the complaint must be served on each other party to the action and filed with the Court. CIT Rule 5(a), 5(d).

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 84(9)

reference.entry.ref.text: Appeal of denial of petition challenging determination as to valuation of merchandise. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations &dblsect;192 to 204, 250 to 319

outline.name.block.name: ComplaintContesting denial by Bureau of Customs and Border Protection of petition challenging classification decision

caption.block.form.line: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

form.para.form.text: [Plaintiff brings/Plaintiffs bring] this action to contest the denial by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection of a petition challenging a classification decision under 28 U.S.C.A. §2631. This Court, therefore, has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b).

[Plaintiff is/Plaintiffs are] the [person/persons] who filed the petition challenging the classification decision. Therefore, [plaintiff has/plaintiffs have] standing to bring this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. §2631(b).
The merchandise subject to classification is [description of merchandise].

form.text.inline.instr: [OPTIONAL: All liquidated duties for the merchandise were paid on [date duties paid].]

form.para.form.text: On [date request was filed], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] filed a written request for information as to the classification of the merchandise in question with the Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection. On [date of receipt of classification by Commissioner], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] received a response indicating [statement of item number of Tariff Schedules of the United States, or heading or subheading of Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States under which merchandise was classified, and rate of duty imposed].

On [date of petition], [plaintiff/plaintiffs] timely filed a petition indicating [his/her/its/their] belief that [tariff description and item number of Tariff Schedules of the United States, or heading or subheading of Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States under which plaintiffs claimed merchandise is properly subject to classification, and rate of duty claimed to be applicable]. By notice dated [date of notice], the Commissioner informed [plaintiff/plaintiffs] that [his/her] original classification was correct.

[Plaintiff renews/Plaintiffs renew] [his/her/its/their] contention that [tariff description and item number of Tariff Schedules of the United States, or heading or subheading of Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States under which plaintiffs claimed merchandise is properly subject to classification, and rate of duty claimed to be applicable]. [Concise allegations of fact and law in support of contentions].

WHEREFORE, [plaintiff requests/plaintiffs request] that this Court enter an order directing the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection to classify the merchandise in question in accordance with the [tariff description and item number/[heading/subheading] of the HTSUS] and rate of duty as set forth by [plaintiff/plaintiffs] in paragraph 7, above.
Dated: [date of complaint]

para.para.text: A complaint filed under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b) contesting the denial of an interested party's challenge to a valuation, classification, or rate of duty determination should set forth: (1) a statement of the basis of the court's jurisdiction; (2) a statement of the plaintiff's standing; (3) a statement that the protest was timely filed; (4) a statement that all liquidated duties have been paid, when appropriate; (5) a description of the merchandise involved; (6) a specification of the contested decision or decisions by the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection; and (7) a demand for judgment for the appropriate relief (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (a)). If the contested decision involves the classification of merchandise, the complaint should also set forth: (a) the item number of the Tariff Schedules of the United States, or the heading or subheading of the Harmonized Tariff Schedules of the United States (HTSUS), including all modifications and amendments thereof, under which the merchandise was classified, and the rate of duty imposed; (b) the tariff description and the item number of the Tariff Schedules of the United States, or the heading or subheading of the HTSUS, including all modifications and amendments thereof, under which the merchandise is claimed to be properly subject to classification, and the rate of duty claimed to be applicable; and (c) concise allegations of the plaintiff's contentions of fact and law in support of the above (Court of International Trade Rules, Appendix of Forms, Complaint Allegations (c)).
A copy of the complaint must be served on each other party to the action and filed with the Court. CIT Rule 5(a), 5(d).

name.block.name: PETITION FOR DEPOSITION TO PERPETUATE TESTIMONY

form.para.form.text: Petitioner, [name of petitioner], by its attorney and pursuant to Rule 27(a) of the Rules of this Court, petitions the Court for an order authorizing plaintiff to take the deposition of [name of deponent] for the purpose of perpetuating [his/her] testimony. In support of this petition, petitioner alleges the following:
Petitioner expects to be a party in an action cognizable in the Court of International Trade but is currently unable to bring such action or cause the action to be brought.
The subject matter of the expected action is [description of subject matter], and petitioner's interest in the action is as follows: [description of interest in action].

Petitioner expects that the adverse parties in the expected action will be [name of party], of [address of party], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state],and [name of additional party], of [address of additional party], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state].
The liquidation of Entry No. [number of entry], the subject of the instant protest, occurred on [date of liquidation].
Petitioner duly made protest on [date of protest] to the District Director of Customs at the port of [description of port].
The merchandise at issue was classified as [description of classification].
The merchandise at issue was improperly classified. The proper classification of the merchandise is [description of classification].
Petitioner desires to perpetuate the testimony of [name of deponent], who resides at [address of deponent], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state].
The substance of the testimony that petitioner expects to elicit from [name of deponent] is [description of testimony].
By use of this testimony petitioner desires to establish the facts that [description of facts sought to be established].

The taking and preservation of the testimony of [name of deponent] is necessary because [name of deponent] is seriously ill with stomach cancer and is not expected to live more than [number of months], as more fully appears from the attached affidavit of [name of affiant].
Petitioner is unable to serve and file a notice of trial at the present time for the reason that [description of reasons for failure to file].
WHEREFORE, petitioner requests that the Court issue an order authorizing petitioner to take the depositions of the above-named persons for the purpose of perpetuating their testimony.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

statnote.note.text: A verified petition for an order to perpetuate testimony must be entitled in the name of the petitioner and must show: (a) that the petitioner expects to be a party to an action cognizable in the Court of International Trade but is currently unable to bring it or cause it to be brought; (b) the subject matter of the expected action and petitioner's interest in it; (c) the facts that petitioner desires to establish by the proposed testimony and petitioner's reasons for desiring to perpetuate it; (d) the names or a description of persons petitioner expects will be adverse parties and their addresses so far as known; and (e) the names and addresses of the persons to be examined and the substance of the testimony that petitioner expects to elicit from each, and must ask for an order authorizing petitioner to take the depositions of the persons to be examined named in the petition, for the purpose of perpetuating their testimony. CIT Rule 27(a).

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85

Depositions under Court of International Trade Rules. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. &dblsect;37:407 et seq.

name.block.name: MOTION FOR DEPOSITION TO PERPETUATE TESTIMONY

form.para.form.text: Plaintiff, by its attorney and pursuant to Rule 27(b) of the Rules of this Court, moves the Court for an order authorizing plaintiff to take the deposition of [name of deponent], who resides at [address of deponent], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state], on [written interrogatories or oral examination] for use in the event of further proceedings before the Court, on the grounds that: (a) plaintiff is appealing the decision of the Court in this action or the time for taking an appeal from the judgment in this action has not yet expired; that [name of deponent] has knowledge of material facts which are not now of record and will establish that [description of facts to be established]; (b) [name of deponent] is [number of years] old and infirm; and (c) unless the testimony of [name of deponent] is perpetuated it will be forever lost if death or other incompetency should intervene.
The substance of the testimony expected to be elicited from [name of deponent] is as follows: [statement of substance of testimony].

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

statnote.note.text: If an appeal has been taken from a judgment or before the taking of an appeal if the time therefore has not expired, the Court of International Trade may allow the taking of depositions of witnesses to perpetuate their testimony for use in the event of further proceedings in the court. In that case the party who desires to perpetuate the testimony may make a motion in the court for leave to take depositions, on the same notice and service as if the action was pending. The motion must show (1) the name and addresses of the persons to be examined and the substance of the testimony which the party expects to elicit from each; and (2) the reasons for perpetuating their testimony. CIT Rule 27(b).

form.para.form.text: [Name of attorney], attorney for plaintiff, moves this Court, in accordance with Court of International Trade Rule 30(a), for leave to take the testimony of [name of Customs Import Specialist], whose business address is the U.S. Customs House, in [name of city], [name of county], [name of state], [ZIP code], by deposition on oral examination prior to the expiration of 30 days after service of the complaint on defendant. Plaintiff moves to take the deposition at [time of deposition] on [date of deposition], at the offices of [name of attorney], in Room [number of room] of the [identification of building], at [address of building], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state].

It is further moved that [name of Import Specialist] be ordered to bring with [him/her] all documents and tangible things in [his/her] possession, relating to the classification of [description of merchandise] under Items [numbers], Tariff Schedules of the United States, generally, and all documents and tangible things in [his/her] possession, relating to the classification of the merchandise covered by entries [description of entries].

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

para.para.text: After service of the complaint, any party may take the testimony of any person, including a party, by deposition on oral examination. Leave of court, granted with or without notice, must be obtained only if the plaintiff seeks to take a deposition prior to the expiration of 30 days after service of the complaint on any defendant, except that leave is not required (1) if a defendant has served a notice of taking deposition or otherwise sought discovery, or (2) if special notice is given as provided in CIT Rule 30(b)(7). CIT Rule 30(a).

form.para.form.text: On reading and filing the motion of [name of attorney], attorney for plaintiff, to depose [name of Import Specialist], and [his/her] request for the production at the taking of the deposition of all documents and other tangible things relating to the classification of the merchandise covered by entries [description of entries], and on all the papers and proceedings had in this matter, it is
ORDERED that the motion for an order to depose [name of Import Specialist] is granted, and it is further

ORDERED that [name of Import Specialist] be directed to appear at [time of deposition], on [date of deposition], at the offices of [name of attorney], in Room [number of room], of the [description of building] Building, at [address of building], [name of city], [name of county], [name of state], on service of a subpoena, pursuant to Rule 45(d) of the Rules of the Court of International Trade, to be examined by plaintiff's counsel, regarding matters relevant to the issues in this proceeding, and it is further

ORDERED that, on service of the subpoena under Rule 45(d) [name of Import Specialist] bring with [him/her] all documents and tangible things in [his/her] possession, relating to the classification of [description of merchandise] under Items [numbers], Tariff Schedules of the United States, generally, and all documents and tangible things in [his/her] possession, relating to the classification of the merchandise covered by entries [description of entries], and it is further
ORDERED that plaintiff cause to be served a subpoena on [name of Import Specialist] at least [number of working days] prior to the date of examination, and it is further

ORDERED that the Clerk of the Court shall, at plaintiff's expense, prepare and forward certified copies of the original entry papers for entries [description of entries] contained in Court File [number of court file], for plaintiff's use in deposing [name of Import Specialist], and it is further
ORDERED that plaintiff provide its own reportorial service at its own expense.
Entered on [date of entry of order].

para.para.text: After service of the complaint, any party may take the testimony of any person, including a party, by deposition on oral examination. Leave of court, granted with or without notice, must be obtained only if the plaintiff seeks to take a deposition prior to the expiration of 30 days after service of the complaint on any defendant, except that leave is not required (1) if a defendant has served a notice of taking deposition or otherwise sought discovery, or (2) if special notice is given as provided in CIT Rule 30(b)(7). CIT Rule 30(a).

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85

reference.entry.ref.text: Practice and procedure in United States Court of International Trade. Am. Jur. 2d, Customs Duties and Import Regulations §286
Depositions under Court of International Trade Rules. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:407 et seq.

para.para.text: This subdivision contains forms and material pertaining to such pretrial proceedings as consolidation of cases, extension of time during which causes of action may remain in reserve file, suspension, and notice of trial.

Joint hearings and consolidation of matters under a common complaint may be ordered when actions involve a common question of law or fact. This course is proper if, for instance, several plaintiffs have commenced separate actions challenging antidumping duty determinations regarding one class of merchandise from one country over one specified time period, and the court finds that it cannot resolve the controversy without reaching the common questions presented in the various actions. The court may also make orders which will tend to avoid unnecessary costs or delay. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:465.

Separate trials may be ordered on claims, cross claims, counterclaims, or third-party claims, or on particular issues in order to economically expedite the case, further convenience, or avoid prejudice. When ordering separate trials, the court must always preserve a party's constitutional or statutory right to a jury trial. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:465.

After the pleadings have been completed and the issue has been joined, an unassigned case is placed on the Joined Issue Calendar. A case may remain on the Joined Issue Calendar for a six-month period which runs from the last day of the month in which the answer was filed until the last day of the sixth month thereafter. The case is removed from the Joined Issue Calendar by requesting a trial. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:346.

Once the issue is joined in one action, it may be designated as a test case, and later, related actions may be suspended as soon as a summons is filed. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. &dblsect;37:294, 37:346.

At the expiration of the applicable six-month period, an unassigned action on the Joined Issue Calendar will be dismissed for lack of prosecution. At least 30 days prior to the expiration of this period, the clerk sends notice to the parties informing them that the action will be dismissed. Unless a motion is presented before the expiration of this time period, the clerk will enter an order of dismissal without further direction from the court. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:347.

An action commenced by the filing of a summons without a complaint is placed on the Reserve Calendar. An action may stay on the Reserve Calendar for an 18-month period, computed from the last day of the month in which the action was commenced until the last day of the 18th month thereafter. An action is removed from the Reserve Calendar:
on assignment;
on the filing of a complaint;
on the granting of a motion for consolidation pursuant to CIT Rule 42;
on the granting of a motion for suspension under a test case pursuant to CIT Rule 84; or
on the filing of a stipulation for judgment on an agreed statement of facts pursuant to Rule 58.1.6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:289.

At least 30 days prior to the expiration of the 18-month period described above, the clerk will notify the parties in writing that the action will be dismissed for lack of prosecution unless it is removed from the Reserve Calendar within that time period. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:290.

A motion may be filed for an extension of time within which an action may remain on the Reserve Calendar, and the clerk may not dismiss the action for lack of prosecution while such a motion is pending. The motion must specifically designate the cases affected by the motion. A motion based on the work load of the plaintiff's attorneys may be denied, however, if the court believes that the attorneys had adequate time to prepare their cases and were given sufficient notice that the cases would be dismissed for lack of prosecution unless removed from the Reserve Calendar. If the motion is denied, and less than 10 days remain before the expiration of the 18-month period during which a case may remain on the Reserve Calendar, the action will remain on the Reserve Calendar for 10 days after entry of the order denying the extension. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:291.

Unless a motion for an extension is pending, an action that is not removed from the Reserve Calendar within the prescribed 18-month period will be dismissed for lack of prosecution. The clerk will enter the order of dismissal without further direction from the court. 9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:291.

The suspension and test case procedure may be used when several actions are filed under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(a) challenging the denial of a protest, or under 28 U.S.C.A. §1581(b) challenging an administrative determination on a petition filed by American interests regarding the appraisal, classification, or rate of duty on imported merchandise. Under the procedure, the other cases are suspended pending the final determination of a test case. An action may be suspended if it involves an issue of fact or a question of law which is the same as an issue of fact or question of law involved in the test case. 10West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:294.

A test case must either be submitted to the court for decision, or be so designated by court order. The order may be obtained on a motion made after the issue is joined. 11West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:295.

After the designation of a test case, a motion for suspension may be filed. Besides complying with the general requirements for motions, the motion must include: (1) the title and court number of the action for which suspension is requested; (2) the title and court number of the test case; and (3) a concise statement of the issue of fact or question of law alleged to be the same in both actions. The motion for suspension may be made at any time, and may be joined with a motion for designation of a test case. 12West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:296.

An order suspending an action stays all further proceedings and the need to file papers in the suspended action, unless the court directs otherwise. 13West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:296.

A motion for removal is required, if a party desires to take a case off the Suspension Calendar, for the purpose of a final disposition. The motion for removal will be granted only for this reason. An order granting a motion to remove a case from the Suspension Calendar must description of the terms, conditions, and period of time within which the action must be finally concluded. 14West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:297.

A suspended case is placed on the Suspension Disposition Calendar after the test case is finally determined, dismissed, or discontinued. Once a case is placed on the Suspension Disposition Calendar, it may remain there for a period of time established by either the judge to whom the action was designed or by the judge who decided the test case. In any event, the case may not remain on the Suspension Disposition Calendar for more than 18 months. 15West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:298.
An action may be removed from the Suspension Disposition Calendar on:
the filing of a complaint;
the filing for a demand for an answer, if the complaint is previously filed;
the granting of a motion for consolidation pursuant to CIT Rule 42;
the granting of a dispositive motion;
the filing for a request for trial; or
the granting of a motion for removal.16West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:299.

The clerk will notify the parties of the date on which an action will be dismissed for lack of prosecution unless it is removed from the Suspension Disposition Calendar. If the action is not removed from the Suspension Disposition Calendar within the established time period, it will be dismissed for lack of prosecution, unless a motion is pending to extend the time during which the case may remain on the calendar. If such a motion is denied and less than 10 days remain in which the action may remain on the Suspension Disposition Calendar, the action will remain on the calendar for 10 days from entry of the order denying the motion. The order dismissing the case for lack of prosecution will be rendered by the clerk without further direction of the court. 17West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:300.

A party who wants an action tried in the Court of International Trade must confer with the opposing party or parties and attempt to reach agreement regarding the time and place of trial. That party must then file a request for trial and serve it on opposing parties. This request may be filed and served any time after the issue is joined, but must generally be filed and served at least 30 days prior to the requested trial date, unless the court permits other reasonable notice for good cause shown. A party who opposes the request must serve and file its opposition within 10 days after the request is served. These procedures and time limits may be altered by court order. 18West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:453.

headnote.note.text: NEW TEST HEADNOTE Statute that imposed greater limits on criminal defendant's ability to take pretrial depositions than on civil defendant's ability to take pretrial depositions did not violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; equal protection clause does not require that civil and criminal defendants have identical discovery rights. U.S. Const. Amend. 14 . McDole v. State, 339 Ark. 391, 6 S.W.3d 74 (1999).

para.para.text: A party who wants an action tried in the Court of International Trade must confer with the opposing party or parties and attempt to reach agreement regarding the time and place of trial. (CIT Rule 40(a)(1)) That party must then file a request for trial and serve it on opposing parties. (CIT Rule 40(a)(2)) This request may be filed and served any time after the issue is joined, but must generally be filed and served at least 30 days prior to the requested trial date, unless the court permits other reasonable notice for good cause shown. (CIT Rule 40(a)) A party who opposes the request must serve and file its opposition within 10 days after the request is served. These procedures and time limits may be altered by court order. (CIT Rule 40(a)).

statnote.note.text: In all instances where a trial is requested to be held at a location other than or in addition to the courthouse at One Federal Plaza, New York, New York, all other parties shall serve and file a response within 10 days after the service of the request, unless a shorter period is directed by the court. CIT Rule 40(a).

para.para.text: The above form is based on Form 6 of the Appendix of Forms (Appendix A) of the Rules of the United States Court of International Trade. A request substantially in this form must be used by a party filing a request for trial. CIT Rule 40(a).
