form.para.form.text: At the pretrial conference held on [date of conference] before the Hon. [name of judge], and attended by counsel, the following matters were discussed and agreed to, and are ORDERED:

General. The parties recognize that this pretrial order controls the subsequent course of the action unless the order is modified by consent of the parties and the Court, or by order of the Court to prevent manifest injustices. The attached schedules, each on a separate sheet, are part of this order.
Parties and Counsel. Schedule A sets forth the names of all parties; the names, addresses and telephone numbers of their respective attorneys, and the names of trial counsel for each party.
Jurisdiction. Schedule B-1 sets forth the statutes, legal doctrines, and facts upon which Plaintiff claims jurisdiction. Schedule B-2 indicates which of these, if any, are contested.

Uncontested Facts. All material facts that are without substantial controversy are set forth in Schedule C. Material facts that are actually and in good faith controverted, and which a party intends to establish at trial, are separately listed in Schedules C-1, C-2, etc. Facts not included in these schedules may be established at trial.
Claims and Defenses. The parties' claims and defenses are separately listed in Schedule D-1, D-2, etc.
Financial and Other Relief. Claims with respect to financial and other relief sought by each party are detailed in Schedules E-1, E-2, etc.
Waiver of Claims. The parties waive all claims with respect to liability, damages, and other relief and all affirmative defenses which are not set forth in Schedules D and E.

Triable Issues. Schedule F sets forth and separately numbers the issues of the case, without simply restating the disputed facts. All legal issues are to be addressed prior to the commencement of the trial. If the parties cannot agree as to the issues, then their separate statement of the issues shall be set forth as Schedules F-1, F-2, etc.
Witnesses. Schedule G-1, G-2, etc. list for the respective parties the witnesses they will or will probably call to testify at the trial, setting forth for each witness:
name;
address;
a summary of expected testimony, and for expert witnesses;
a curriculum vitae; and
the area of expertise.

Deposition Testimony. Any party proposing to use deposition testimony as evidence shall, at least two weeks prior to the trial date, notify all the adversaries of the testimony proposed to be read. Objections to any proposed deposition testimony shall be made in writing no later than one week prior to trial. The parties shall file with the Court copies of the depositions, indicating the parts to be read and the relative objections. The Court will rule on all such objections prior to commencement of the trial.

Exhibits. Schedules H-1, H-2, etc. list for the respective parties the exhibits to be offered in evidence by that party. Each list shall identify and description of each exhibit. Plaintiff's exhibits shall be identified by numbers, Defendant's by letters. The parties recognize that they will not be allowed to use at trial any exhibits or witnesses not identified in this pretrial order except upon prompt notice to all parties and to the Court, and upon a showing of good cause.

Objections to Exhibits. Schedules I-1, I-2, etc. list for the respective parties each adversary's exhibits whose authenticity and admissibility are contested. The parties shall state the specific ground for objection to each contested exhibit listed.
Discovery. All discovery is complete. Undisclosed discovery which surfaces during trial will be deemed untimely and subject to the sanction of exclusion.
Pretrial Legal Memoranda. Not fewer than seven days before the trial, each counsel shall provide the Court with memoranda of law containing:
a statement of the facts which the party intends to establish at trial.
the supporting evidence which the party intends to introduce at trial.
a discussion addressing all the legal issues in dispute.
Filing will be deemed completed when received.
Trial Time. The trial will take approximately [number of days].
Entered on [date of entry of order].

cite.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85

reference.entry.ref.text: Request for trial in Court of International Trade. Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:453

para.para.text: This subdivision contains forms and material pertaining to judgments in the Court of International Trade, including summary judgments.

Summary judgment is appropriate if there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. A party should move for summary judgment if the opponent does not dispute or deny any facts alleged by the party, but only challenges the party's interpretation of those facts and the legal consequences that flow from same. Summary judgment for the defendant is also proper if the uncontroverted evidence supports a complete defense to the action. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:442.

A party who has filed a claim may move for summary judgment at any time after the expiration of the initial time within which an adverse party may file an answer. A claimant may also move for summary judgment after an adverse party files a motion for summary judgment. For the purpose of the CIT Rules, a claimant includes any party seeking to recover on a claim, counterclaim, cross claim, or a claim for declaratory judgment. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:443.

A person who is defending against a claim, counterclaim, cross claim, or claim for declaratory judgment may move for summary judgment at any time after the complaint is filed. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:443.

However, in some cases, leave of court is required if a motion for summary judgment might delay proceedings. Accordingly, a motion for summary judgment may not be filed by any party, except by order of the court on motion, after: (1) the action has been set for trial; (2) the filing of a stipulation of the parties or a pretrial memorandum containing all the material facts; or (3) that party has filed a response to a motion for summary judgment presented by an adverse party. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:443.

A request for summary judgment requires the filing of a motion, which may be accompanied by supporting affidavits, although the filing of supporting affidavits is not absolutely necessary. The motion should conform to the general formal requirements for any dispositive motion. In addition, the movant must attach to the motion a separate, short, and concise statement of the material facts which the movant contends present no genuine issue to be tried. 5West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:444.

Assuming that the movant has properly supported the motion for summary judgment by affidavits, deposition testimony, answers to interrogatories or the like, the adverse party may not rest on the mere allegations or denials in his or her pleadings, but must file affidavits or otherwise establish through answers to discovery requests specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial. In addition, the party opposing the motion must also include a separate, short, and concise statement of material facts which form the basis of the contention that there is a genuine issue to be tried. Material facts in the movant's statement will be deemed admitted unless controverted in the statement served by the responding party, and summary judgment will be entered against a party who does not properly bolster the allegations in his or her pleading with supporting affidavits or the like, if this action is appropriate. Note that CIT Rule 56(f) states that summary judgment will be entered against a party who does not respond "if appropriate," meaning that if the parties agree that there is no genuine issue of material fact or if the government does not controvert the facts described in an importer's statement, all facts supported by the importer will be deemed admitted, but the government may still argue that the importer merchandise is properly classifiable to one item in the Tariff Schedules, while the importer may claim that a different classification is proper. 6West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:445.

If an opposing party presents an affidavit which specifies reasons why that party cannot obtain facts needed to oppose the motion for summary judgment, the court may refuse to grant the motion or may order a continuance to give the opponent an opportunity to obtain affidavits or conduct further discovery. 7West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:445.

Affidavits filed in support of or in opposition to a motion for summary judgment must be made on personal knowledge. The affidavit must set forth facts that would be admissible in evidence and affirmatively show that the affiant is competent to testify to the matter stated in the affidavit. Sworn or certified copies of all papers, or parts of papers, referred to in an affidavit must be attached to the affidavit or served with it. However, an affiant may refer to papers and documents which are part of the official agency record on review filed in the Court of International Trade without attaching copies of these documents and without additional certification. Affidavits may be supplemented or opposed by depositions, answers to interrogatories, or further affidavits. 8West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:446.

If it appears that any of the affidavits presented on a motion for summary judgment were presented in bad faith or solely for the purpose of delay, the court may order the amending party to pay for the other party the amount of the reasonable expenses which the filing of the affidavits in bad faith caused him or her to incur, including reasonable attorney's fees, and any offending party may be found guilty of contempt. 9West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:446.

A party may request a hearing and oral argument on a motion for summary judgment. Summary judgment will be rendered immediately if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, admissions on file, and any affidavits show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. 10West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:447.

Partial summary judgment may be granted if judgment is not rendered on the whole case or for all relief requested, and a trial is necessary on the remaining claims. However, partial summary judgment is not appropriate if the movant does not seek the resolution of all or some part of a claim, but only the reduction of its burden of proof. 11West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:448.

At the hearing on the motion for partial summary judgment, the court must examine the pleadings and the evidence for it and interrogate counsel in order to ascertain what material facts exist without substantial controversy and what material facts are controverted in good faith. The court will then make an order describing the facts that appear without substantial controversy, including the extent to which the amount of damages and other claims for relief are not in controversy, and directing such further proceedings in the action as are just. The facts so specified will be deemed established at trial, and the trial will be conducted accordingly. 12West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:448.

Under CIT Rule 56.1, if a party believes that the determination of the Court of International Trade is to be made solely on the basis of the record made before an agency, that party may move for judgment in its favor on all or any part of the agency determination. This motion may be made any time after the issue is joined. A response to a motion for judgment on an agency record must be served within 30 days after service of the motion. The moving party has 10 days after service of the response to the motion to serve a reply. No other papers or briefs are allowed, except by leave of court. 13West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:449.

When a motion for judgment on an agency record is filed by a party, an opposing party may not file a cross-motion for judgment on an agency record. If the court determines that judgment ought to be entered in favor of an opposing party, it may enter judgment in favor of that party, notwithstanding the absence of a cross-motion. 14West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:449.

In addition to other requirements prescribed by the CIT Rules regarding the form of briefs, briefs submitted on the motion in support of or in opposition to the agency determination must include a statement setting forth the following matters in separately numbered paragraphs: (1) the administrative determination sought to be reviewed with appropriate references to the Federal Register; and (2) the issues of law presented together with the reasons for contesting or supporting the administrative determination, a description of how the determination may be arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, not otherwise in accordance with the law, unsupported by substantial evidence; or, how the determinations may be unwarranted by the facts to the extent that the agency may or may not have considered facts which, as a matter of law, should or should not have been properly considered. The brief must include the authorities relied on and the conclusions of law deemed warranted by the authorities. All references to the administrative record must be made by citing the parts of the record to the factual or legal issues raised. Citations must be by page number of the transcript, if any, and by specific identification of exhibits together with the relevant page number. 15West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:450.

Challenges to the denial of a protest or to an administrative determination on a petition regarding the classification, valuation, or rate of duty on imported merchandise may be submitted on a stipulation for judgment on an agreed statement of facts. This action may be taken at any time, without the need to file a brief, a complaint, or a formal amendment of any pleading. 16West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:451.

A proposed stipulated judgment on an agreed statement of facts should be in substantially the official form (CIT Rules Appendix A, Form 9. The plaintiff must serve the proposed stipulation on the Attorney-in-Charge, International Trade Field Office, Commercial Litigation Branch, Department of Justice, and within five days of service must also advise the court in writing the proposed stipulation has been served. The Attorney-in-Charge may refer the matter to the appropriate Customs officials. An authorized Customs official may delete a protest or entry number from a schedule of protest or entry numbers attached to or embodied in a statement of the brief facts by drawing a line through the number and initialing the change. Once there is agreement, the parties must file with the clerk of the Court of International Trade the stipulation signed by the parties or by their attorneys, together with a proposed stipulated judgment. 17West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:452.
The term "judgment" as used in the CIT Rules includes a decree and any order on which an appeal lies. 18West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:521.

The Court of International Trade has the power to render money judgments, or order any other form of relief as appropriate in a civil action, including, but not limited to, declaratory judgments, orders of remand, injunctions, and writs of mandamus and prohibition. All judgments, except default judgments, must give the prevailing party all relief to which he or she is entitled, even if that party has not demanded such relief in his or her pleadings. 19West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:531.

CIT Rule 54(b) permits the Court of International Trade to render judgment on some claims or for or against some parties in a multiclaim or multiparty case on an express direction for the entry of judgment and an express determination that there is no reason for delay. The rule covers situations when more than one claim for relief is presented, whether a claim, counterclaim, cross claim, or third-party claim, and the rendering of judgment in a multiparty or multiclaim case is appropriate where the court ordered separate trials on counterclaims and crossclaims, even if the claims of the opposing party have been dismissed or otherwise determined. 20West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:522.

A partial judgment becomes final only if the proper direction and determination have been made, and, in the absence of the direction and determination, any order or decision which does not dispose of all claims by or against all parties is not a final judgment with respect to any party or claim. Such a nonfinal "judgment" is subject to revision by the Court of International Trade at any time before the entry of a final judgment which adjudicates all rights and liabilities. 21West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:522.

A party against whom a claim for affirmative relief is made may be found in default if that party has failed to plead or otherwise defend in the manner prescribed by the CIT Rules. The clerk will enter a default against such a party if the fact of the default is made to appear by affidavit or otherwise. The opposing party may then apply to the court for a default judgment. A judgment by default may be sought by a plaintiff, a third-party plaintiff, a crossclaimant, or a counterclaimant. If the party against whom a default judgment is sought has appeared in the action, that party or his or her representative must be served within 10 days' written notice of the application for judgment. 22West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:526.

Appealable final determinations, except dismissals for lack of prosecution, must be evidenced by a judgment, decree, or final order. A judgment, decree, or final order must be set forth on a separate document, signed by the court. The judgment may not contain a recital of the pleadings, a master's report, or the record of prior proceedings. 23West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:528.

A party need only submit a proposed form of judgment when directed by the court or required to do so by the CIT Rules. 24West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:528.

The clerk of the Court of International Trade enters judgment in the Civil Docket, and a judgment is not effective until it is entered. The docket sheet must show the date the judgment is entered. On entry, the clerk must serve on each party, and on the district director of the Customs District when the action arose, if appropriate, a notice of entry of judgment by delivery or mail, together with a copy of the judgment, opinion, decision, or findings of fact and conclusions of law on which the judgment was based. The clerk also records judgments and appealable orders, together with supporting documents, in the Judgment and Order Book, which becomes a permanent document in the clerk's office. 25West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:529.

Lack of notice of the entry of a judgment does not affect the time to appeal a case or authorize the court to relieve a party for failure to appeal within the allowed time, except as permitted by the rules of the appellate court. 26West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:529.

form.name.block.name: UNITED STATES COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE

entry.ital: action, as applicable, including name of

name.block.name: STATEMENT IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFF'S MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT

form.para.form.text: It is plaintiff's position that consideration of the pleadings and the affidavit of [name of affiant], which is attached, clearly shows that there is no genuine issue of fact and that the questions for this Court are of law.
Taken together, it is submitted that for the purpose of the instant motion, the pleadings and affidavits establish the following facts:
Plaintiff is the importer of record on the entries involved in this matter (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).
The subject entries were liquidated: at the duties indicated on the attached schedule (complaint, paragraph number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).

The protests were duly filed with the Regional Commissioner of Customs at New York on the dates indicated on the attached schedule (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).
All liquidated: duties have been paid (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph number of paragraph]).
A summons was timely filed within the period prescribed by law.

The merchandise at issue was classified under Item 682.60, TSUS, at the rate of [description of rate] ad valorem as a "rectifying apparatus" (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]) and defendant's response to plaintiff's request for admissions, paragraph [number of paragraph].

Plaintiff claims the instant merchandise to be properly dutiable under Item 688.40, TSUS at the rate of [description of rate] ad valorem (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).
The specific articles that are the subject of this civil action are [brand name] battery chargers (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).

The [description of merchandise] is designed and intended to be used to test 1.5 volt batteries to determine if they should be recharged (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).
The [description of merchandise] is also designed and intended to be used to recharge 1.5 and 9 volt batteries (complaint, paragraph [number of paragraph]; answer, paragraph [number of paragraph]).
The affidavit of [name of affiant], [description of title or other identification], establishes that:
[He/She] is Professor of Electrical Engineering and Acting Chairperson of the Department of Electrical Engineering at [name of university] (affidavit, paragraph [number of paragraph]).

form.text.inline.instr: [Continuation with other facts in separate subparagraphs].]

form.para.form.text: The issues for the Court's determination concerning plaintiff's motion for summary judgment are whether the words "rectifying apparatus" in Item 682.60, TSUS, encompass the merchandise in question and, if not, whether plaintiff's claimed classification under Item 688.40, TSUS, as "electrical articles, not specially provided for," is correct.

form.text.inline.instr: [Statement, with citations, of legal arguments supporting plaintiff's position.]

form.para.form.text: Since the merchandise in issue, an electrical article, has been designed and manufactured as a combination article intended to perform the two-fold function of [description of functions], the article, as an entirety is more than any of its components and must find classification in a provision of law that will embrace all of its constituent parts.
Accordingly, it is respectfully submitted that summary judgment should be granted holding the merchandise properly dutiable under Item 688.40, TSUS, at the rate of [description of rate] ad valorem.

form.line.inline.instr: [Name of law firm/Name of other entity]

form.para.form.text: I, [name of server], certify that I am associated with the law firm of [name of law firm], with offices at [address], and that on [date of service], I served a copy of the foregoing [description of pleading or paper] on [name of attorney], the attorney of record of [description of party], by [personally delivering a copy/depositing a true copy in a United States mail receptacle, properly enclosed in a securely closed envelope with postage prepaid, addressed] to [name of attorney] at [address of attorney].

statnote.note.text: On any motion for summary judgment, there must be attached to the motion a separate, short, and concise statement of the material facts as to which the moving party contends there is no genuine issue to be tried. The papers opposing a motion for summary must include a separate, short, and concise statement of the material facts as to which it is contended that there exists a genuine issue to be tried. All material facts set forth in the statement required to be served by the moving party will be deemed to be admitted unless controverted by the statement required to be served by the opposing party. CIT Rule 56(i).

para.para.text: The above statement was adapted from a statement and memorandum filed in Fedtro, Inc. v. U. S., 72 Cust. Ct. 267, 376 F. Supp. 1398 (Cust. Ct. 1974), in which the merchandise in question was held to be something more than a rectifying apparatus, as it had been classified by Customs, and to be properly dutiable under the provision in Item 688.40, TSUS, for "electrical articles, not specially provided for," as claimed by plaintiff, and summary judgment was granted for plaintiff.

form.para.form.text: This case having been duly submitted for decision and this Court, after due deliberation, having rendered a decision; now, in conformity with that decision,

IT IS ORDERED, ADJUDGED and DECREED that the claim in protest [number of protest] that merchandise described on the entry invoices as first category is dutiable at [description of rate] ad valorem under TSUS Item [number of item] is sustained; and
The claim in protest [number of protest] with respect to the classification of merchandise described in the entry invoices as second category is overruled; and
The claim in protest [number of protest] with respect to the classification of merchandise described on the entry invoices as third category is overruled.

The District Director of Customs at the port of [description of port] is directed to reliquidate the entry under protest [number of protest] covering that merchandise described as [first category], and make refund accordingly.

para.para.text: The above form is available from Court of International Trade, http://www.cit.uscourts.gov/Rules/rules-forms.htm, and is reprinted here for illustrative purposes.
This subdivision contains forms and materials pertaining to appeals from the Court of International Trade to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.
As to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, see Federal Practice and Procedure. See also Federal Procedure, L. Ed., Appeal, Certiorari, and Review.

A decision of the Court of International Trade is final and conclusive unless a rehearing is granted or an appeal is taken to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit by filing a notice of appeal with the clerk of the Court of International Trade within the time and manner prescribed for taking an appeal from a District Court to a Court of Appeals. 1West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:530.

After the Court of International Trade has rendered a judgment or order, the court may on the motion of a party or on its own motion, grant a retrial or rehearing. A motion of a party or the court must be made not later than 30 days after the date of entry of the judgment or order. 2West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:542.

A notice of appeal must be filed with the clerk of the Court of International Trade in the manner and within the time specified by Rule 4(a) of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure and copies of the notice of appeal must be served as provided by Rule 3(d) of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure. Since the United States or a federal officer or agency is generally a party to an action in the Court of International Trade, a notice of appeal must be filed within 60 days after entry of the judgment, and once notice of appeal is filed by one party, any other party may file a notice within 14 days thereafter or within the original 60-day period from entry of judgment, whichever is longer. The appeal time runs only after the judgment below becomes final. 3West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:564.

Interlocutory appeals are governed by Rule 5 of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure. Within 10 days after entry of an order granting permission to appeal, the appellant must pay to the clerk of the trial court such fees as are established by statute and the docket fee prescribed by Federal Circuit Rule 17, together with a bond for costs, if required pursuant to Rule 7 of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure. A notice of appeal need not be filed. 4West's Key Number Digest, Customs Duties &key;82 to 85.Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:565.

para.para.text: The above form is essentially the form set forth as Form 1, Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure, Appendix of Forms.

Since the clerk of the Court of International Trade is required to serve notice of the filing of a notice of appeal by mailing a copy of the notice to each party, other than the appellant, or to his or her counsel of record, counsel for the appellant should furnish the clerk with a sufficient number of copies of the original notice for this purpose. See Federal Procedure, L. Ed. §37:564.
